original: āgacchanti pariyādiyantevassa cittaṁ; ko pana vādo adhimattānaṁ.
analyzed: āgacchanti citta kaḥ pana vādaḥ
translated: The Connected Discourses with Māra,

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?🔽Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo, so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so appahīno, yo moho so appahīno …pe….🔽Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā jivhāviññeyyesu rasesu yo rāgo so atthi …pe….
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu  yaḥ bhikkhave rāgaḥ saḥ atthi yaḥ doso saḥ atthi yaḥ moho saḥ atthi yaḥ rāgo saḥ appahīnaḥ yaḥ doso saḥ appahīnaḥ yaḥ moho saḥ appahīnaḥ pe yassa kassaci bhikkhave bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyāḥ vā jivhā viññeyyesu rasesu yaḥ rāgaḥ saḥ atthi pe
translated: And why is that?🔽“Whatever desire there is, bhikkhus, whatever greed there is, whatever love there is, whatever passion there is, whatever craving there is for sensual desires, that is not present in him. Whatever desire there is, whatever greed there is, whatever love there is, whatever passion there is, whatever craving there is for form, that is not present in him. Whatever desire there is, whatever greed there is, whatever love there is, whatever passion there is, whatever craving there is for feeling, that is not present in him. Whatever desire there is, whatever greed there is, whatever love there is, whatever passion there is, whatever craving there is for perception, that is not present in him. Whatever desire there is, whatever greed there is, whatever love there is, whatever passion there is, whatever craving there is for volitional formations, that is not present in him. Whatever desire there is, whatever greed there is, whatever love there is, whatever passion there is, whatever craving there is for consciousness, that is not present in him.

original: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā manoviññeyyesu dhammesu yo
analyzed: yassa kassaci bhikkhave bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyāḥ vā manas viññeyyesu dhammesu yaḥ
translated: “Whatever desire there is, bhikkhus, whatever greed there is, whatever love there is, whatever passion there is, whatever craving there is for things connected with the ear…🔽for things connected with the nose…🔽for things connected with the tongue…🔽for things connected with the body…

original: rāgo so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so
analyzed: rāgaḥ saḥ atthi yaḥ doso saḥ atthi yaḥ moho so atthi yaḥ rāgo saḥ appahīnaḥ yaḥ doso so
translated: for things connected with the mind, that is not present in him. Whatever desire there is, whatever greed there is, whatever love there is, whatever passion there is, whatever craving there is for things connected with the mind, that is not present in him.

original: appahīno, yo moho so appahīno, tassa parittā cepi manoviññeyyā dhammā manassa āpāthaṁ🔽āgacchanti pariyādiyantevassa cittaṁ; ko pana vādo adhimattānaṁ.
analyzed: appahīnaḥ yaḥ mohaḥ saḥ appahīno tassa parittā ce pi manaḥ viññeyyā dhammā manassa āpātha  āgacchanti citta kaḥ pana vādaḥ
translated: “If, bhikkhus, things connected with the mind enter the range of the mind, and if he is not intent on some particular object, his mind is seized by those things connected with the mind.

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: “And why is that?

original: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo, so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so appahīno, yo moho so appahīno.
analyzed: yaḥ bhikkhave rāgaḥ saḥ atthi yaḥ doso saḥ atthi yaḥ moho saḥ atthi yaḥ rāgo saḥ appahīnaḥ yaḥ doso saḥ appahīnaḥ yaḥ moho saḥ appahīnaḥ
translated: Lust is present, hatred is present, delusion is present, and they haven’t given up lust, hatred, and delusion.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, khīrarukkho assattho vā nigrodho vā pilakkho vā udumbaro vā daharo taruṇo komārako.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave khīra rukkhaḥ assatthaḥ vā nigrodhaḥ vā pilakkhaḥ vā udumbaraḥ vā daharaḥ taruṇaḥ komārakaḥ
translated: Suppose there were a tree that was sapwood, not heartwood,

original: Tamenaṁ puriso tiṇhāya kuṭhāriyā yato yato ābhindeyya āgaccheyya khīran”ti?
analyzed: tam enam purisaḥ tiṇhāya kuṭhāriyā yatas yatas ābhindeyya āgaccheyya
translated: and a man came with a sharp axe. Wherever he struck the tree, he would be met with sapwood, not heartwood.”

analyzed: eva bhante
translated: “Yes, lord.”

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: “And why is that?”

analyzed: yat hi bhante khīram tam atthi iti
translated: “Because the sapwood is present.”

original: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā cakkhuviññeyyesu
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave yassa kassaci bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā cakkhu viññeyyesu
translated: “In the same way, when a monk or a nun has lust,

original: rūpesu yo rāgo so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno,
analyzed: rūpesu yaḥ rāgaḥ saḥ atthi yaḥ doso saḥ atthi yaḥ moho saḥ atthi yaḥ rāgaḥ saḥ appahīno
translated: hatred, and delusion, and hasn’t given up lust, hatred, and delusion,

original: yo doso so appahīno, yo moho so appahīno, tassa parittā cepi cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā
analyzed: yaḥ doso saḥ appahīno yaḥ moho so appahīno tassa parittā ce pi cakkhu viññeyyā rūpā
translated: even if they see limited forms with the eye,

original: cakkhussa āpāthaṁ āgacchanti pariyādiyantevassa cittaṁ; ko pana vādo adhimattānaṁ.
analyzed: cakkhussa āpātham āgacchanti kaḥ pana vādaḥ
translated: and they come within the visual range of one who has not abandoned it, they obsess his mind. How much more so if he looks at them!

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so appahīno, yo moho so appahīno …pe….
analyzed: yaḥ bhikkhave rāgaḥ saḥ atthi yaḥ doso saḥ atthi yaḥ moho saḥ atthi yaḥ rāgo saḥ appahīnaḥ yaḥ doso saḥ appahīnaḥ yaḥ moho saḥ appahīnaḥ pe
translated: Because there is lust, there is hate, there is delusion. And that lust, hate, and delusion have not been abandoned in him. …

original: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā jivhāviññeyyesu rasesu yo rāgo so atthi …pe….
analyzed: yassa kassaci bhikkhave bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyāḥ vā jivhā viññeyyesu rasesu yaḥ rāgaḥ saḥ atthi pe
translated: “Whoever has lust for tastes cognizable by the tongue that has not been abandoned in him …

original: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā manoviññeyyesu dhammesu yo
analyzed: yassa kassaci bhikkhave bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyāḥ vā manas viññeyyesu dhammesu yaḥ
translated: Whoever has lust for ideas cognizable by the intellect that has not been abandoned in him,

original: rāgo so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so🔽appahīno, yo moho so appahīno, tassa parittā cepi manoviññeyyā dhammā manassa āpāthaṁ
analyzed: rāgaḥ saḥ atthi yaḥ doso saḥ atthi yaḥ moho so atthi yaḥ rāgo saḥ appahīnaḥ yaḥ doso so  appahīnaḥ yaḥ mohaḥ saḥ appahīno tassa parittā ce pi manaḥ viññeyyā dhammā manassa āpātha
translated: there is lust in him. Whoever has hate in him, there is hate in him. Whoever has delusion in him, there is delusion in him. And that lust, hate, and delusion have not been abandoned in him.

original: āgacchanti pariyādiyantevassa cittaṁ; ko pana vādo adhimattānaṁ.
analyzed: āgacchanti citta kaḥ pana vādaḥ
translated: If ideas cognizable by the intellect come into the range of the intellect, they obsess his mind. How much more so if he gives attention to them!

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so appahīno, yo moho so appahīno.
analyzed: yaḥ bhikkhave rāgaḥ saḥ atthi yaḥ doso saḥ atthi yaḥ moho saḥ atthi yaḥ rāgo saḥ appahīnaḥ yaḥ doso saḥ appahīnaḥ yaḥ moho saḥ appahīnaḥ
translated: “Bhikkhus, there is no lust, hate, or delusion in the bhikkhu or bhikkhunī in whom there is no lust, hate, or delusion that has not been abandoned.

original: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu yo🔽rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso
analyzed: yassa kassaci bhikkhave bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā cakkhu viññeyyesu rūpesu yaḥ  rāgaḥ saḥ natthi yaḥ doso saḥ natthi yaḥ moho saḥ natthi yaḥ rāgaḥ saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ doso
translated: If, bhikkhus, the eye were the fetter of forms or if forms were the fetter of the eye, this living of the holy life could not be discerned for the complete destruction of suffering.

original: so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno, tassa adhimattā cepi cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā cakkhussa🔽āpāthaṁ āgacchanti nevassa cittaṁ pariyādiyanti; ko pana vādo parittānaṁ.🔽Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ moho saḥ pahīno tassa adhimattā ce pi cakkhu viññeyyā rūpā cakkhussa  āpātham āgacchanti na iva assa cittam pariyādiyanti kaḥ pana vādaḥ  tam kim sa hetu
translated: But since the eye is not the fetter of forms nor are forms the fetter of the eye, this living of the holy life can be discerned for the complete destruction of suffering.

original: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno …pe….
analyzed: yaḥ bhikkhave rāgaḥ saḥ natthi yaḥ doso saḥ natthi yaḥ moho saḥ natthi yaḥ rāgo saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ doso saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ moho saḥ pahīnaḥ pe
translated: “Bhikkhus, there is no lust, hate, or delusion in the bhikkhu or bhikkhunī in whom there is no lust, hate, or delusion that has not been abandoned.

original: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā jivhāviññeyyesu rasesu …pe…
analyzed: yassa kassaci bhikkhave bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyāḥ vā jivhā viññeyyesu rasesu pe
translated: If, bhikkhus, the ear were the fetter of sounds or if sounds were the fetter of the ear …🔽If, bhikkhus, the nose were the fetter of odours or if odours were the fetter of the nose …🔽If, bhikkhus, the tongue were the fetter of flavours or if flavours were the fetter of the tongue …

original: manoviññeyyesu dhammesu yo rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi,
analyzed: manaḥ viññeyyesu dhammesu yaḥ rāgaḥ saḥ natthi yaḥ doso saḥ natthi yaḥ moho saḥ natthi
translated: There is no lust, hatred, or delusion in regard to mental phenomena cognizable by the mind.

original: yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno, tassa adhimattā cepi manoviññeyyā
analyzed: yaḥ rāgaḥ saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ doso saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ moho so pahīno tassa adhimattā ce pi manaḥ viññeyyā
translated: Any lust, hatred, or delusion has been abandoned.

original: dhammā manassa āpāthaṁ āgacchanti nevassa cittaṁ pariyādiyanti; ko pana vādo parittānaṁ.
analyzed: dhammā manassa āpātham āgacchanti na iva assa cittam pariyādiyanti kaḥ pana vādaḥ
translated: Even if loud sounds come within the range of the ear, they do not obsess the mind. How much less so the soft ones!

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno.
analyzed: yaḥ bhikkhave rāgaḥ saḥ natthi yaḥ doso saḥ natthi yaḥ moho saḥ natthi yaḥ rāgo saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ doso saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ moho saḥ pahīnaḥ
translated: Because any lust, hatred, or delusion has been abandoned.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, khīrarukkho assattho vā nigrodho vā pilakkho vā udumbaro vā sukkho kolāpo terovassiko.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave khīrarukkhaḥ assatthaḥ vā nigrodhaḥ vā pilakkhaḥ vā udumbaraḥ vā sukkhaḥ kolāpaḥ terovassikaḥ
translated: Suppose there were a teak tree, an assattha tree, a fig tree, or a banyan tree—a large tree with luxuriant foliage—

original: Tamenaṁ puriso tiṇhāya kuṭhāriyā yato yato ābhindeyya āgaccheyya khīran”ti?
analyzed: tam enam purisaḥ tiṇhāya kuṭhāriyā yatas yatas ābhindeyya āgaccheyya
translated: and a man came with a sharp axe. From whatever side he struck it, would sap come out?”

analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: “Why is that?”

analyzed: yat hi bhante khīram tat natthi iti
translated: “Because, venerable sir, the sap has been removed.”

original: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā cakkhuviññeyyesu🔽rūpesu yo rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno,
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave yassa kassaci bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā cakkhu viññeyyesu  rūpesu yaḥ rāgaḥ saḥ natthi yaḥ doso saḥ natthi yaḥ moho saḥ natthi yaḥ rāgaḥ saḥ pahīno
translated: “So too, bhikkhus, for any bhikkhu or bhikkhunī in whom greed, hatred, and delusion have been abandoned,

original: yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno, tassa adhimattā cepi cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā cakkhussa
analyzed: yaḥ doso saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ moho so pahīno tassa adhimattā ce pi cakkhu viññeyyā rūpā cakkhussa
translated: in whom greed, hatred, and delusion have been abandoned, even if they were to encounter excessive, extreme, painful, sharp, severe, and bitter feelings,

original: āpāthaṁ āgacchanti nevassa cittaṁ pariyādiyanti; ko pana vādo parittānaṁ.
analyzed: āpātham āgacchanti na iva assa cittam pariyādiyanti kaḥ pana vādaḥ
translated: they would not be able to overpower their mind. How much less so by minor ones?

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?🔽Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno …pe….🔽Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā jivhāviññeyyesu rasesu …pe….
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu  yaḥ bhikkhave rāgaḥ saḥ natthi yaḥ doso saḥ natthi yaḥ moho saḥ natthi yaḥ rāgo saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ doso saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ moho saḥ pahīnaḥ pe  yassa kassaci bhikkhave bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyāḥ vā jivhā viññeyyesu rasesu pe
translated: Why is that?🔽Because greed, hatred, and delusion have been abandoned in them. …🔽“For any bhikkhu or bhikkhunī in whom greed, hatred, and delusion have been abandoned,

original: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā manoviññeyyesu dhammesu yo
analyzed: yassa kassaci bhikkhave bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyāḥ vā manas viññeyyesu dhammesu yaḥ
translated: in whom greed, hatred, and delusion have been abandoned, even if they were to encounter excessive, extreme, painful, sharp, severe, and bitter feelings,🔽they would not be able to overpower their mind.

original: rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso🔽so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno, tassa adhimattā cepi manoviññeyyā dhammā manassa āpāthaṁ
analyzed: rāgaḥ saḥ natthi yaḥ doso saḥ natthi yaḥ moho saḥ natthi yaḥ rāgaḥ saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ doso  saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ moho saḥ pahīno tassa adhimattā ce pi manaḥ viññeyyā dhammā manassa āpātha
translated: There is no lust, there is no hate, there is no delusion. Any lust is abandoned, any hate is abandoned, any delusion is abandoned.🔽Even if loud sounds come within the range of the ear, his mind isn’t enthralled with them. How much less so the soft ones?🔽Even if scents come within the range of the nose…🔽Even if tastes come within the range of the tongue…🔽Even if touches come within the range of the body…

original: āgacchanti, nevassa cittaṁ pariyādiyanti; ko pana vādo parittānaṁ.
analyzed: āgacchanti na iva assa cittam pariyādiyanti kaḥ pana vādaḥ
translated: Even if thoughts come within the range of the mind, his mind isn’t enthralled with them. How much less so the feeble ones?

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno”ti.
analyzed: yaḥ bhikkhave rāgaḥ saḥ natthi yaḥ doso saḥ natthi yaḥ moho saḥ natthi yaḥ rāgo saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ doso saḥ pahīnaḥ yaḥ moho saḥ pahīno ti
translated: There is no lust, there is no hate, there is no delusion. Any lust is abandoned, any hate is abandoned, any delusion is abandoned.”

translated: The fourth.

analyzed: sayutta nikāya
translated: Saṃyutta Nikāya 54.18

analyzed: samuddavagga
translated: . The Ocean

analyzed: koṭṭhika sutta
translated: Koṭṭhita

original: Ekaṁ samayaṁ āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca mahākoṭṭhiko bārāṇasiyaṁ viharanti isipatane migadāye.
analyzed: ekam samayam āyasmā ca sāriputtaḥ āyasmā ca mahākoṭṭhikaḥ bārāṇasiyam viharanti isipatane migadāye
translated: One time the venerable Sāriputta and the venerable Mahā Koṭṭhita were staying at Bārāṇasī in the Deer Park at Isipatana.

original: Atha kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṁ sammodi.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhikaḥ sāyanha samayam paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitaḥ yena āyasmā sāriputto tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhim sammodi
translated: Then, in the evening, the venerable Mahā Koṭṭhita came out of seclusion and approached the venerable Sāriputta. He exchanged greetings with the venerable Sāriputta and sat down to one side.

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko āyasmantaṁ sāriputtaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhikaḥ āyasmantam sāriputtam etat avoca
translated: and when this courteous and amiable talk was finished, he sat down at one side and said to the Venerable Sariputta:

original: “Kiṁ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, cakkhu rūpānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, rūpā cakkhussa saṁyojanaṁ …pe…
analyzed: kim nu kho āvuso sāriputta cakkhu rūpānaṃ sayojana rūpā cakkhussa sayojanam pe
translated: “Now, friend Sariputta, is the eye the fetter of forms or are forms the fetter of the eye …

original: jivhā rasānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, rasā jivhāya saṁyojanaṁ …pe…
analyzed: jivhā rasānam sayojana rasā jivhāya sayojanam pe
translated: is the ear the fetter of sounds … is the nose the fetter of odours … is the tongue the fetter of flavours …

original: mano dhammānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, dhammā manassa saṁyojanan”ti?
analyzed: manaḥ dhammānam sayojana dhammā manassa sayojananti
translated: is the mind the fetter of mental phenomena or are mental phenomena the fetter of the mind?”

original: “Na kho, āvuso koṭṭhika, cakkhu rūpānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, na rūpā cakkhussa saṁyojanaṁ.
analyzed: na kho āvuso koṭṭhika cakkhu rūpānaṃ sayojana na rūpā cakkhussa sayojana
translated: “Friend Kotthita, the eye is not the fetter of forms nor are forms the fetter of the eye,

original: Yañca tattha tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo taṁ tattha saṁyojanaṁ …pe…
analyzed: yat ca tattha tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati chanda rāgaḥ tam tattha sayojanam pe
translated: but the desire and lust that arise there in dependence on both is the fetter there.

original: na jivhā rasānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, na rasā jivhāya saṁyojanaṁ.🔽Yañca tattha tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo taṁ tattha saṁyojanaṁ …pe…
analyzed: na jivhā rasānam sayojana na rasā jivhāya sayojana  yat ca tattha tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati chanda rāgaḥ tam tattha sayojanam pe
translated: The ear is not the fetter of sounds …

original: na mano dhammānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, na dhammā manassa saṁyojanaṁ.
analyzed: na manaḥ dhammānam sayojana na dhammā manassa sayojana
translated: The mind is not the fetter of mental phenomena nor are mental phenomena the fetter of the mind,🔽but the desire and lust that arise there in dependence on both is the fetter there.

original: Yañca tattha tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo taṁ tattha saṁyojanaṁ.
analyzed: yat ca tattha tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati chanda rāgaḥ tam tattha sayojana
translated: The desire and passion that arise there in dependence on both: that is the fetter here.

original: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, kāḷo ca balībaddo odāto ca balībaddo ekena dāmena vā yottena vā saṁyuttā assu.🔽Yo nu kho evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: seyyathā api āvuso kāḷaḥ ca balībaddo odātaḥ ca balībaddo ekena dāmena vā yottena vā sayuttāḥ assu  yaḥ nu khalu evam vadeyya
translated: Suppose a black ox and a white ox were yoked together by a single harness or yoke.🔽If someone were to say, ‘The black ox is the fetter of the white ox, the white ox is the fetter of the black ox,’

original: ‘kāḷo balībaddo odātassa balībaddassa saṁyojanaṁ, odāto balībaddo kāḷassa balībaddassa saṁyojanan’ti, sammā nu kho so vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?🔽“No hetaṁ, āvuso”.
analyzed: kāḷaḥ balībaddo odātassa balībaddassa sayojanaḥ odātaḥ balībaddo kāḷassa balībaddassa sayojananti sammā nu kho saḥ vadamānaḥ vadeyya ati  na u ha itas āvuso
translated: would he be speaking rightly?”🔽“No, friend.

original: “Na kho, āvuso, kāḷo balībaddo odātassa balībaddassa saṁyojanaṁ, na odāto balībaddo kāḷassa balībaddassa saṁyojanaṁ.
analyzed: na kho āvuso kāḷaḥ balībaddo odātassa balībaddassa sayojana na odātaḥ balībaddo kāḷassa balībaddassa sayojana
translated: The black ox is not the fetter of the white ox, nor is the white ox the fetter of the black ox.

original: Yena ca kho te ekena dāmena vā yottena vā saṁyuttā taṁ tattha saṁyojanaṁ.
analyzed: yena ca khalu te ekena dāmena vā yottena vā sayuttā tam tattha sayojana
translated: But rather the single harness or yoke by which they are yoked together: that is the fetter there.

original: Evameva kho, āvuso, na cakkhu rūpānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, na rūpā cakkhussa saṁyojanaṁ.
analyzed: evam eva kho āvuso na cakkhu rūpānam sayojana na rūpā cakkhussa sayojana
translated: In the same way, friend, the eye is not the fetter of forms, nor are forms the fetter of the eye.

original: Yañca tattha tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo taṁ tattha saṁyojanaṁ …pe…
analyzed: yat ca tattha tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati chanda rāgaḥ tam tattha sayojanam pe
translated: The fetter there is the desire and lust that arise there in dependence on both. …

analyzed: na jivhāḥ rasānam sayojanam pe
translated: The tongue is not the fetter of tastes …

original: na mano dhammānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, na dhammā manassa saṁyojanaṁ.
analyzed: na manaḥ dhammānam sayojana na dhammā manassa sayojana
translated: The mind is not the fetter of mental phenomena, nor are mental phenomena the fetter of the mind.

original: Yañca tattha tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṁ tattha saṁyojanaṁ.
analyzed: yat ca tattha tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati chanda rāgaḥ tam tattha sayojana
translated: The fetter there is the desire and lust that arise there in dependence on both.

original: Cakkhu vā, āvuso, rūpānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ abhavissa, rūpā vā cakkhussa saṁyojanaṁ, nayidaṁ brahmacariyavāso paññāyetha sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
analyzed: cakkhu vai āvuso rūpānam sayojanam abhavissa rūpā vā cakkhussa sayojana na yidam brahmacariya vāsaḥ paññāyetha sammā dukkha kkhayāya
translated: “If the eye were the fetter of visible forms, or if visible forms were the fetter of the eye, this living of the holy life could not be discerned for the complete destruction of suffering.

original: Yasmā ca kho, āvuso, na cakkhu rūpānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, na rūpā cakkhussa saṁyojanaṁ;
analyzed: yasmā ca kho āvuso na cakkhu rūpānam sayojana na rūpā cakkhussa sayojana
translated: But since the eye is not the fetter of visible forms, nor are visible forms the fetter of the eye,🔽the living of the holy life for the complete destruction of suffering is discerned. …🔽“If the ear were the fetter of sounds …🔽If the nose were the fetter of odours …

original: yañca tattha tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṁ tattha saṁyojanaṁ, tasmā brahmacariyavāso paññāyati sammā dukkhakkhayāya …pe….
analyzed: yat ca tattha tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati chanda rāgaḥ tam tattha tasmā brahmacariya vāso paññāyati sammā dukkha kkhayāya pe
translated: If the tongue were the fetter of tastes …🔽If the body were the fetter of tactile objects …🔽If the mind were the fetter of mental phenomena, or if mental phenomena were the fetter of the mind, this living of the holy life could not be discerned for the complete destruction of suffering.🔽But since the mind is not the fetter of mental phenomena, nor are mental phenomena the fetter of the mind,

original: Jivhā, āvuso, rasānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ abhavissa, rasā vā jivhāya saṁyojanaṁ, nayidaṁ brahmacariyavāso paññāyetha sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
analyzed: jivhā āvuso rasānam sayojanam abhavissa rasāḥ vā jivhāya sayojana na yidam brahmacariya vāsaḥ paññāyetha sammā dukkha kkhayāya
translated: If the tongue were a fetter for tastes, or if tastes were a fetter for the tongue, this living of the holy life could not be discerned for the complete destruction of suffering.

original: Yasmā ca kho, āvuso, na jivhā rasānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, na rasā jivhāya saṁyojanaṁ; yañca
analyzed: yasmai ca khalu āvuso na jivhā na rasā jivhāya sayojana yat ca
translated: But since the tongue is not a fetter for tastes, nor are tastes a fetter for the tongue,

original: tattha tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṁ tattha saṁyojanaṁ, tasmā brahmacariyavāso
analyzed: tattha tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati chanda rāgaḥ tam tattha tasmā brahmacariya vāso
translated: but rather the desire and lust that arise there in dependence on the two of them: that is the fetter there,

analyzed: paññāyati sammā dukkha kkhayāya pe
translated: that is why the living of the holy life is discerned for the complete destruction of suffering.

original: Mano vā, āvuso, dhammānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ abhavissa, dhammā vā manassa saṁyojanaṁ, nayidaṁ brahmacariyavāso paññāyetha sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
analyzed: manaḥ va āvuso dhammānam sayojanam abhavissa dhammāḥ vā manassa sayojana na idam brahmacariya vāsaḥ paññāyetha sammā dukkha kkhayāya
translated: “If the mind were a fetter for mental phenomena, or if mental phenomena were a fetter for the mind, this living of the holy life could not be discerned for the complete destruction of suffering.

original: Yasmā ca kho, āvuso, na mano dhammānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, na dhammā manassa saṁyojanaṁ;
analyzed: yasmā ca kho āvuso na manaḥ dhammānam sayojana na dhammā manassa sayojana
translated: But since the mind is not a fetter for mental phenomena, nor are mental phenomena a fetter for the mind,

original: yañca tattha tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṁ tattha saṁyojanaṁ, tasmā brahmacariyavāso paññāyati sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
analyzed: yat ca tattha tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati chanda rāgaḥ tam tattha tasmā brahmacariya vāso paññāyati sammā dukkha kkhayāya
translated: but rather the desire and lust that arise there in dependence on the two of them: that is the fetter there, that is why the living of the holy life is discerned for the complete destruction of suffering.

original: Imināpetaṁ, āvuso, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā na cakkhu rūpānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, na rūpā cakkhussa saṁyojanaṁ.
analyzed: iminā apeta āvuso pariyāyena veditabbam yathā na cakkhu rūpānam sayojana na rūpā cakkhussa sayojana
translated: In this way too, friends, it can be understood how the eye is not the fetter of forms nor are forms the fetter of the eye,

analyzed: yat ca tattha tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati chanda rāgaḥ tam tattha sayojanam pe

translated: The mind is not the fetter of mental phenomena nor are mental phenomena the fetter of the mind,

translated: “A black bull is not the bond of a white bull, nor is a white bull the bond of a black bull.

original: Yena ca kho te ekena dāmena vā yottena vā saṁyuttā, taṁ tattha saṁyojanaṁ.
analyzed: yena ca khalu te ekena dāmena vā yottena vā sayuttā tam tattha sayojana
translated: But rather the rope or the halter by which they are tethered is the bond there.

original: Evameva kho, āvuso, na cakkhu rūpānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, na rūpā cakkhussa saṁyojanaṁ …pe…🔽na jivhā …pe…
analyzed: evam eva kho āvuso na cakkhu rūpānam sayojana na rūpā cakkhussa sayojanam pe  na jivhā pe
translated: In the same way, friend, the eye is not the bond of forms, nor are forms the bond of the eye.

analyzed: na manaḥ pe
translated: The ear is not the bond of sounds…🔽The mind is not the bond of mental phenomena, nor are mental phenomena the bond of the mind.

original: yañca tattha tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṁ tattha saṁyojanan”ti.
analyzed: yat ca tattha tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati chanda rāgaḥ tam tattha sayojananti
translated: But rather the desire and lust that arise there in dependence on both is the bond there.”

analyzed: chaṭṭha
translated: The sixth.

analyzed: sayutta nikāya
translated: Saṁyutta Nikāya 35.137–146

analyzed: samuddavagga
translated: The Samudda Group

analyzed: udāyī sutta
translated: With Udāyī

original: Ekaṁ samayaṁ āyasmā ca ānando āyasmā ca udāyī kosambiyaṁ viharanti ghositārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam āyasmā ca ānandaḥ āyasmā ca udāyī kosambiyam viharanti ghosita ārāme
translated: At one time the venerable Ānanda and the venerable Udāyī were staying at Kosambī in the Ghosita Park.

original: Atha kho āyasmā udāyī sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṁ sammodi.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmai udāyī sāyanha samayam paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitaḥ yena āyasmai ānandaḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhim sammodi
translated: Then, in the evening, the venerable Udāyī came out of retreat, approached the venerable Ānanda, exchanged greetings,

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā udāyī āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho āyasmai udāyī āyasmantam ānandam etat avoca
translated: and said to him:

original: “Yatheva nu kho, āvuso ānanda, ayaṁ kāyo bhagavatā anekapariyāyena akkhāto vivaṭo pakāsito:
analyzed: yathā iva nu khalu āvuso ānanda ayam kāyaḥ bhagavatā aneka pariyāyena akkhātaḥ vivaṭaḥ pakāsitaḥ
translated: “Friend Ānanda, just as the Blessed One has in many a figure revealed, described, and made known the body as a something that is not self,

original: ‘itipāyaṁ kāyo anattā’ti, sakkā evameva viññāṇaṁ pidaṁ ācikkhituṁ desetuṁ paññapetuṁ paṭṭhapetuṁ vivarituṁ vibhajituṁ uttānīkātuṁ: ‘itipidaṁ viññāṇaṁ anattā’”ti?
analyzed: iti pā ayam kāyaḥ anattā ati sakkā evam eva viññāṇam pidam ācikkhitum desetum paññapetum paṭṭhapetum vivaritum vibhajitum iti pidam viññāṇam anattā ati
translated: can he in the same way reveal, describe, and make known consciousness as a something that is not self?”

original: “Yatheva kho, āvuso udāyī, ayaṁ kāyo bhagavatā anekapariyāyena akkhāto vivaṭo pakāsito:
analyzed: yathā iva kho āvuso udāyī ayam kāyaḥ bhagavatā aneka pariyāyena akkhātaḥ vivaṭaḥ pakāsitaḥ
translated: “Friend Udāyī, just as the Blessed One has in many a figure revealed, described, and made known the body as a something that is not self,

original: ‘itipāyaṁ kāyo anattā’ti, sakkā evameva viññāṇaṁ pidaṁ ācikkhituṁ desetuṁ paññapetuṁ paṭṭhapetuṁ vivarituṁ vibhajituṁ uttānīkātuṁ: ‘itipidaṁ viññāṇaṁ anattā’”ti.
analyzed: iti pā ayam kāyaḥ anattā ati sakkā evam eva viññāṇam pidam ācikkhitum desetum paññapetum paṭṭhapetum vivaritum vibhajitum iti pidam viññāṇam anattā ati
translated: ‘This body is not-self,’ so too it is not possible to point to consciousness and say: ‘This is consciousness, this is not consciousness, this is how consciousness is, or is not.’

original: “Cakkhuñca, āvuso, paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇan”ti?
analyzed: cakkhuñca āvuso paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhu viññāṇanti
translated: “Is eye-consciousness caused by and conditions the eye and forms?”

analyzed: evam āvuso iti
translated: “Yes.”

original: “Yo cāvuso, hetu, yo ca paccayo cakkhuviññāṇassa uppādāya, so ca hetu, so ca paccayo sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ aparisesaṁ nirujjheyya. Api nu kho cakkhuviññāṇaṁ paññāyethā”ti?
analyzed: yaḥ ca āvuso hetu yaḥ ca paccayaḥ cakkhu viññāṇassa uppādāya saḥ ca hetu saḥ ca paccayo sabbena sabbam sabbathā sabbam aparisesam nirujjheyya api nu kho cakkhu viññāṇam paññāyetha ati
translated: “If the cause and condition for the arising of eye-consciousness were to cease completely and totally without remainder, could eye-consciousness be discerned?”

analyzed: na u ha itas āvuso
translated: “No, friend.”🔽

original: “Imināpi kho etaṁ, āvuso, pariyāyena bhagavatā akkhātaṁ vivaṭaṁ pakāsitaṁ: ‘itipidaṁ viññāṇaṁ anattā’”ti …pe….
analyzed: iminā api kho ete āvuso pariyāyena bhagavatā akkhātam vivaṭam pakāsitaḥ iti pi idam viññāṇam anattā ati pe
translated: “In this way too, friend, this has been declared, disclosed and revealed by the Lord: ‘Thus this consciousness is not-self.’ …

analyzed: jivham ca āvuso paṭicca rase ca uppajjati jivhā viññāṇam ti
translated: “Is tongue-consciousness caused by and conditions the tongue and tastes?”

analyzed: evam āvuso iti
translated: “Yes.”

original: “Yo cāvuso, hetu yo ca paccayo jivhāviññāṇassa uppādāya, so ca hetu, so ca paccayo sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ aparisesaṁ nirujjheyya, api nu kho jivhāviññāṇaṁ paññāyethā”ti?
analyzed: yaḥ ca āvuso hetu yaḥ ca paccayaḥ jivhā viññāṇassa uppādāya saḥ ca hetu saḥ ca paccayaḥ sabbena sabbam sabbathā sabbam aparisesam nirujjheyya api nu kho jivhā viññāṇam paññāyetha ati
translated: “If the cause and condition for the arising of tongue-consciousness were to cease completely and totally without remainder, would tongue-consciousness be discerned?”

analyzed: na u ha itas āvuso
translated: “No, friend.”

original: “Imināpi kho etaṁ, āvuso, pariyāyena bhagavatā akkhātaṁ vivaṭaṁ pakāsitaṁ: ‘itipidaṁ viññāṇaṁ anattā’”ti …pe….
analyzed: iminā api kho ete āvuso pariyāyena bhagavatā akkhātam vivaṭam pakāsitaḥ iti pi idam viññāṇam anattā ati pe
translated: “In this way too, friend, this has been declared, disclosed, and revealed by the Blessed One thus: ‘For such a reason this consciousness is nonself.’ …

analyzed: manam ca āvuso paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manaḥ viññāṇanti
translated: “Dependent on the mind and mental phenomena, mind-consciousness arises.”

analyzed: evam āvuso iti
translated: “Yes, friend.”

original: “Yo cāvuso, hetu, yo ca paccayo manoviññāṇassa uppādāya, so ca hetu, so ca paccayo sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ aparisesaṁ nirujjheyya, api nu kho manoviññāṇaṁ paññāyethā”ti?
analyzed: yaḥ ca āvuso hetu yaḥ ca paccayaḥ manaḥ viññāṇassa uppādāya saḥ ca hetu saḥ ca paccayaḥ sabbena sabbam sabbathā sabbam aparisesam nirujjheyya api nu kho manaḥ viññāṇam paññāyetha ati
translated: “If the cause and condition for the arising of mind-consciousness were to cease completely and totally without remainder, would mind-consciousness be discerned?”

analyzed: na u ha itas āvuso
translated: “No, friend.”

original: “Imināpi kho etaṁ, āvuso, pariyāyena bhagavatā akkhātaṁ vivaṭaṁ pakāsitaṁ: ‘itipidaṁ viññāṇaṁ anattā’ti.
analyzed: iminā api kho ete āvuso pariyāyena bhagavatā akkhātam vivaṭam pakāsitaḥ iti pi idam viññāṇam anattā ati
translated: “In this way too, friend, this has been declared, disclosed, and revealed by the Blessed One thus: ‘For such a reason this consciousness is nonself.’ …

original: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṁ caramāno tiṇhaṁ kuṭhāriṁ
analyzed: seyyathā api āvuso purisaḥ sāratthikaḥ sāra gavesī sāra pariyesanam caramānaḥ tiṇham kuṭhāri
translated: Just as if a man needing heartwood, seeking heartwood, wandering in search of heartwood, would take a sharp axe and enter a forest.🔽

original: ādāya vanaṁ paviseyya. So tattha passeyya mahantaṁ kadalikkhandhaṁ ujuṁ navaṁ akukkukajātaṁ.🔽Tamenaṁ mūle chindeyya; mūle chetvā agge chindeyya; agge chetvā pattavaṭṭiṁ vinibbhujeyya.
analyzed: ādāya vanam paviseyya saḥ tattha passeyya mahantam kadali kkhandham ujum navam a kukkuka jāta  tam enam mūle chindeyya mūle chetvā agge chindeyya agge chetvā patta vaṭṭim vinibbhujeyya
translated: Just as if a man needing heartwood, seeking heartwood, wandering in search of heartwood, would take a sharp axe and enter the forest. There he would see a large plantain trunk, straight, young, without fruit-bud core.🔽He would cut it at the root, cut off the top, and unroll the leaf-sheaths.

original: So tattha pheggumpi nādhigaccheyya, kuto sāraṁ.
analyzed: saḥ tattha pheggum pi na adhigaccheyya kutas
translated: But even if he were to search carefully, he would not find even softwood, let alone heartwood.

original: Evameva kho, āvuso, bhikkhu chasu phassāyatanesu nevattānaṁ na attaniyaṁ samanupassati.
analyzed: evam eva kho āvuso bhikkhu chasu phassa āyatanesu na iva attānam na attaniyam samanupassati
translated: In the same way, a bhikkhu does not regard the six bases of contact as self or as belonging to self.

original: So evaṁ asamanupassanto na kiñci loke upādiyati.
analyzed: so evam a samanupassantaḥ na kiñci loke upādiyati
translated: Since he does not regard them thus, he does not cling to anything in the world.

original: Anupādiyaṁ na paritassati. Aparitassaṁ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati.
analyzed: anupādiyam na paritassati a paritassam paccattaññā iva parinibbāyati
translated: Not clinging, he is not agitated. Not being agitated, he personally attains nibbāna.

original: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti iti
translated: He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’“🔽So it was with reference to this that it was said: “One should not run back to the past… “

analyzed: sattama  sayutta nikāya  samuddavagga
translated: The Book of the Fives

analyzed: ādittapariyāyasutta
translated: The Discourse on the Simile of the Burning🔽Thus have I heard.

analyzed: ādittapariyāyam vaḥ bhikkhave dhamma pariyāyam desessāmi
translated: “Monks, I will teach you a discourse on burning.

analyzed: tam suṇātha
translated: Listen & pay close attention. I will speak.

analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave ādittapariyāyaḥ dhammapariyāyo
translated: “And what is the discourse on burning?

original: Varaṁ, bhikkhave, tattāya ayosalākāya ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya cakkhundriyaṁ sampalimaṭṭhaṁ, na tveva cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu anubyañjanaso nimittaggāho.🔽Nimittassādagathitaṁ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṁ tiṭṭhamānaṁ tiṭṭheyya, anubyañjanassādagathitaṁ🔽vā tasmiñce samaye kālaṁ kareyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjati, yaṁ dvinnaṁ gatīnaṁ aññataraṁ gatiṁ gaccheyya—
analyzed: vara bhikkhave tattāya ayosalākāya ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajoti bhūtāya cakkhu indriyam na tu eva cakkhu viññeyyesu rūpesu anubyañjanasaḥ nimitta ggāhaḥ  nimitta ssāda gathitam vā bhikkhave viññāṇam tiṭṭhamānam tiṭṭheyya anubyañjana ssāda gathita  vā tasmin ce samaye kālam kareyya ṭhānam etam vijjati yam dvinnam gatīnam aññataram gatim gaccheyya
translated: It would be better, monks, for the eye faculty to be lacerated by a red-hot iron pin burning, blazing, & glowing, than for one to grasp for the sign consisting in the appearance of forms cognizable by the eye.🔽If consciousness were to stand tied to gratification in the sign consisting in the appearance of forms cognizable by the eye, and if one were to die on that occasion, it would be said of one thus dead that he has drunk the drink of the devas.

analyzed: nirayam vā tiracchānayonim vā
translated: But if consciousness were to stand tied to gratification in the sign consisting in the appearance of forms cognizable by the eye, and if one were to die on that occasion, it would be said of one thus dead that he has drunk the drink of the devas.

original: Imaṁ khvāhaṁ, bhikkhave, ādīnavaṁ disvā evaṁ vadāmi.
analyzed: imam khvā āha bhikkhave ādīnavam disvā evam vadāmi
translated: Seeing this danger, I say.

original: Varaṁ, bhikkhave, tiṇhena ayosaṅkunā ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena sotindriyaṁ sampalimaṭṭhaṁ, na tveva sotaviññeyyesu saddesu anubyañjanaso nimittaggāho.
analyzed: bhikkhave tiṇhena ayosaṅkunā ādittena sampajjalitena sajoti bhūtena sotindriyam na tu eva sota viññeyyesu saddesu nimitta ggāhaḥ
translated: “Monks, it would be better for the ear faculty to be lacerated by a red-hot iron pin burning, blazing, and glowing, than for one to grasp the sign through the features in sounds cognizable by the ear.

original: Nimittassādagathitaṁ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṁ tiṭṭhamānaṁ tiṭṭheyya, anubyañjanassādagathitaṁ
analyzed: nimitta ssāda gathitam vā bhikkhave viññāṇam tiṭṭhamānam tiṭṭheyya anubyañjana ssāda gathita
translated: “If consciousness were to stand tied to pleasure in the sign and tied to pleasure in the features,

original: vā tasmiñce samaye kālaṁ kareyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjati, yaṁ dvinnaṁ gatīnaṁ aññataraṁ gatiṁ gaccheyya—
analyzed: vā tasmin ce samaye kālam kareyya ṭhānam etam vijjati yam dvinnam gatīnam aññataram gatim gaccheyya
translated: and if one were to die on that occasion, it is possible that one would go to one of two destinations:

original: nirayaṁ vā tiracchānayoniṁ vā.🔽Imaṁ khvāhaṁ, bhikkhave, ādīnavaṁ disvā evaṁ vadāmi.
analyzed: nirayam vā tiracchānayonim vā  imam khvā āha bhikkhave ādīnavam disvā evam vadāmi
translated: the hell realm or the animal realm.🔽“Seeing this danger, I say that one should not grasp the sign through the features in sounds cognizable by the ear.

original: Varaṁ, bhikkhave, tiṇhena nakhacchedanena ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena ghānindriyaṁ sampalimaṭṭhaṁ, na tveva ghānaviññeyyesu gandhesu anubyañjanaso nimittaggāho.
analyzed: vara bhikkhave tiṇhena nakha chedanena ādittena sampajjalitena sajoti bhūtena ghāna indriyam na tu eva ghāna viññeyyesu gandhesu nimitta ggāhaḥ
translated: “Monks, it would be better for the nose faculty to be lacerated by a sharp iron stake burning, blazing, and glowing, than for one to grasp the sign through the features in odours cognizable by the nose.

original: Nimittassādagathitaṁ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṁ tiṭṭhamānaṁ tiṭṭheyya, anubyañjanassādagathitaṁ vā tasmiñce samaye kālaṁ kareyya.
analyzed: nimitta ssāda gathitam vā bhikkhave viññāṇam tiṭṭhamānam tiṭṭheyya anubyañjana ssāda gathitam vā tasmin ce samaye kālam kareyya
translated: Or the consciousness of one attached to the taste of signs might remain for a day and a night, or for two days and nights, or for three days and nights, or for four days and nights, or for five days and nights, or for six days and nights, or for a week, or for two weeks, or for three weeks, or for a month, or for two months, or for three months, or for four months, or for five months, or for six months, or for a year, or for two years, or for three years, or for four years, or for five years, or for ten years, or for twenty years, or for thirty years, or for forty years, or for fifty years, or for a hundred years, or for a thousand years, or for a hundred thousand years, or even longer than that.🔽It’s possible that at that time one might die.

original: Ṭhānametaṁ vijjati, yaṁ dvinnaṁ gatīnaṁ aññataraṁ gatiṁ gaccheyya—
analyzed: ṭhānam etam vijjati yam dvinnam gatīnam aññataram gatim gaccheyya
translated: If one were to die at that time, it’s possible that one would go to one of two destinations:

analyzed: nirayam vā tiracchānayonim vā
translated: hell or the animal realm.🔽Seeing this danger, I say this.

original: Imaṁ khvāhaṁ, bhikkhave, ādīnavaṁ disvā evaṁ vadāmi.🔽Varaṁ, bhikkhave, tiṇhena khurena ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena jivhindriyaṁ sampalimaṭṭhaṁ, na tveva jivhāviññeyyesu rasesu anubyañjanaso nimittaggāho.
analyzed: imam khvā āha bhikkhave ādīnavam disvā evam vadāmi  vara bhikkhave tiṇhena khurena ādittena sampajjalitena sajoti bhūtena jivhā indriyam na tu eva jivhā viññeyyesu rasesu anubyañjanaso nimitta ggāhaḥ
translated: It would be better, monks, to have a red-hot iron spike driven into one’s eye than to enjoy sensual pleasures.

original: Nimittassādagathitaṁ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṁ tiṭṭhamānaṁ tiṭṭheyya, anubyañjanassādagathitaṁ vā tasmiñce samaye kālaṁ kareyya.
analyzed: nimitta ssāda gathitam vā bhikkhave viññāṇam tiṭṭhamānam tiṭṭheyya anubyañjana ssāda gathitam vā tasmin ce samaye kālam kareyya
translated: Or the consciousness of one attached to the taste of signs might remain for a day and a night, or for two days and nights, or for three days and nights, or for four days and nights, or for five days and nights, or for six days and nights, or for a week, or for two weeks, or for three weeks, or for a month, or for two months, or for three months, or for four months, or for five months, or for six months, or for a year, or for two years, or for three years, or for four years, or for five years, or for ten years, or for twenty years, or for thirty years, or for forty years, or for fifty years, or for a hundred years, or for a thousand years, or for a hundred thousand years, or even longer than that.🔽It’s possible that at that time one might die.

original: Ṭhānametaṁ vijjati, yaṁ dvinnaṁ gatīnaṁ aññataraṁ gatiṁ gaccheyya—🔽nirayaṁ vā tiracchānayoniṁ vā.
analyzed: ṭhānam etam vijjati yam dvinnam gatīnam aññataram gatim gaccheyya 🔽nirayam vā tiracchānayonim vā
translated: If one were to die at that time, it’s possible that one would go to one of two destinations:

original: Imaṁ khvāhaṁ, bhikkhave, ādīnavaṁ disvā evaṁ vadāmi.
analyzed: imam khvā āha bhikkhave ādīnavam disvā evam vadāmi
translated: Seeing this danger, I say this.

original: Varaṁ, bhikkhave, tiṇhāya sattiyā ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya kāyindriyaṁ sampalimaṭṭhaṁ, na tveva kāyaviññeyyesu phoṭṭhabbesu anubyañjanaso nimittaggāho.🔽Nimittassādagathitaṁ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṁ tiṭṭhamānaṁ tiṭṭheyya, anubyañjanassādagathitaṁ vā tasmiñce samaye kālaṁ kareyya.🔽Ṭhānametaṁ vijjati, yaṁ dvinnaṁ gatīnaṁ aññataraṁ gatiṁ gaccheyya—
analyzed: bhikkhave tiṇhāya sattiyai ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajoti bhūtāya kāya indriyam na tu eva kāya viññeyyesu phoṭṭhabbesu anubyañjanasaḥ nimitta ggāhaḥ  nimitta ssāda gathitam vā bhikkhave viññāṇam tiṭṭhamānam tiṭṭheyya anubyañjana ssāda gathitam vā tasmin ce samaye kālam kareyya  ṭhānam etam vijjati yam dvinnam gatīnam aññataram gatim gaccheyya
translated: It would be better, bhikkhus, to have full confidence in the body faculty, which is aflame, burning, and ablaze, than to take up and pursue signs through the body faculty.🔽If consciousness were to stand attached to the sign in the body faculty, delighting in it, relishing it, and remaining fastened to it, and if at that time one were to die, it would be possible that one would go either to hell or to the animal realm.

analyzed: nirayam vā tiracchānayonim vā
translated: It is possible that one would go to one of these two realms.

original: Imaṁ khvāhaṁ, bhikkhave, ādīnavaṁ disvā evaṁ vadāmi.
analyzed: imam khvā āha bhikkhave ādīnavam disvā evam vadāmi
translated: Seeing this danger, I say this.

analyzed: vara bhikkhave sotta
translated: It would be better, bhikkhus, to sleep.

original: Sottaṁ kho panāhaṁ, bhikkhave, vañjhaṁ jīvitānaṁ vadāmi, aphalaṁ jīvitānaṁ vadāmi,
analyzed: sottam kho pana āha bhikkhave vañjham jīvitānam vadāmi aphalam jīvitānam vadāmi
translated: I say that sleep is a barren state, a fruitless state,

original: momūhaṁ jīvitānaṁ vadāmi, na tveva tathārūpe vitakke vitakkeyya yathārūpānaṁ vitakkānaṁ
analyzed: momūham vadāmi na tu eva tathārūpe vitakke vitakkeyya
translated: a deluded state, and that one should not think thoughts connected with such states.

analyzed: vasam gataḥ saṅgham bhindeyya
translated: and would split the Saṅgha.

original: Imaṁ khvāhaṁ, bhikkhave, vañjhaṁ jīvitānaṁ ādīnavaṁ disvā evaṁ vadāmi.
analyzed: imam khvā āha bhikkhave vañjham jīvitānam ādīnavam disvā evam vadāmi
translated: Seeing this danger in a barren life, I say this.

original: Tattha, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: tattha bhikkhave sutavā ariya sāvakaḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, the instructed noble disciple considers thus:

original: ‘tiṭṭhatu tāva tattāya ayosalākāya ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya cakkhundriyaṁ sampalimaṭṭhaṁ.
analyzed: tiṭṭhatu tāva tattāya ayosalākāya ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajoti bhūtāya cakkhu indriyam
translated: ‘Let be the burning with a red-hot iron pin piercing through both feet and hands.

analyzed: handa aham idam eva manasi karomi
translated: Let me just attend to this:

original: iti cakkhu aniccaṁ, rūpā aniccā, cakkhuviññāṇaṁ aniccaṁ, cakkhusamphasso anicco,
analyzed: iti cakkhu anicca rūpā aniccā cakkhu viññāṇam anicca cakkhu samphassaḥ aniccaḥ
translated: Thus the eye is impermanent, forms are impermanent, eye-consciousness is impermanent, eye-contact is impermanent,

original: yampidaṁ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tampi aniccaṁ’.
analyzed: yat pi idam cakkhu samphassa paccayā uppajjati vedayitam sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā tat pi anicca
translated: and whatever feeling arises with eye-contact as condition … that too is impermanent.’

original: Tiṭṭhatu tāva tiṇhena ayosaṅkunā ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena sotindriyaṁ sampalimaṭṭhaṁ.
analyzed: tiṭṭhatu tāva tiṇhena ayosaṅkunā ādittena sampajjalitena sajoti bhūtena sotindriyam
translated: ‘Let be the burning with a red-hot iron nail piercing through the skull and brain.

analyzed: handa aham idam eva manasi karomi
translated: Let me just attend to this:

original: iti sotaṁ aniccaṁ, saddā aniccā, sotaviññāṇaṁ aniccaṁ, sotasamphasso anicco, yampidaṁ
analyzed: iti sotam anicca saddāḥ aniccā sota viññāṇam anicca sota samphassaḥ aniccaḥ
translated: In this way, the ear is impermanent, sounds are impermanent, ear-consciousness is impermanent, ear-contact is impermanent,

original: sotasamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tampi aniccaṁ.
analyzed: sota samphassa paccayā uppajjati vedayitam sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā tam pi anicca
translated: and whatever feeling arises because of ear-contact—whether pleasant, painful, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant—that too is impermanent.

original: Tiṭṭhatu tāva tiṇhena nakhacchedanena ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena ghānindriyaṁ sampalimaṭṭhaṁ.
analyzed: tiṭṭhatu tāva tiṇhena nakha chedanena ādittena sampajjalitena sajoti bhūtena gha an indriyam
translated: Leave aside burning the nose with a sharp razor.

analyzed: handa aham idam eva manasi karomi
translated: I will focus on this:🔽In this way, the nose is impermanent, smells are impermanent, nose-consciousness is impermanent, nose-contact is impermanent,

original: iti ghānaṁ aniccaṁ, gandhā aniccā, ghānaviññāṇaṁ aniccaṁ, ghānasamphasso anicco, yampidaṁ ghānasamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ …pe… tampi aniccaṁ.
analyzed: iti ghānam anicca gandhāḥ aniccāḥ ghāna viññāṇam anicca ghāna samphassaḥ aniccaḥ yam pidam ghāna samphassa paccayā uppajjati vedayitam pe tam pi anicca
translated: and whatever feeling arises because of nose-contact—whether pleasant, painful, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant—that too is impermanent.

original: Tiṭṭhatu tāva tiṇhena khurena ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena jivhindriyaṁ sampalimaṭṭhaṁ.
analyzed: tiṭṭhatu tāva tiṇhena khurena ādittena sampajjalitena sajoti bhūtena jivhindriyam
translated: Leave aside burning the tongue with a sharp razor.

analyzed: handa aham idam eva manasi karomi
translated: I will focus on this:

original: iti jivhā aniccā, rasā aniccā, jivhāviññāṇaṁ aniccaṁ, jivhāsamphasso anicco, yampidaṁ jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati …pe… tampi aniccaṁ.
analyzed: iti jivhā aniccā rasāḥ aniccā jivhā viññāṇam anicca jivhā samphassaḥ aniccaḥ yam pidam jivhā samphassa paccayā uppajjati pe tampi anicca
translated: In this way, the tongue is impermanent, tastes are impermanent, tongue-consciousness is impermanent, tongue-contact is impermanent, and whatever feeling arises because of tongue-contact—whether pleasant, painful, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant—that too is impermanent.

original: Tiṭṭhatu tāva tiṇhāya sattiyā ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya kāyindriyaṁ sampalimaṭṭhaṁ.
analyzed: tiṭṭhatu tāva tiṇhāya sattiyai ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajoti bhūtāya kāya indriyam
translated: Leave aside the body being crushed with a sharp spear.

analyzed: handa aham idam eva manasi karomi
translated: I will just think about this:

original: iti kāyo anicco, phoṭṭhabbā aniccā, kāyaviññāṇaṁ aniccaṁ, kāyasamphasso anicco, yampidaṁ kāyasamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ …pe… tampi aniccaṁ.
analyzed: iti kāyaḥ aniccaḥ phoṭṭhabbāḥ aniccā kāya viññāṇam anicca kāya samphassaḥ aniccaḥ yam pidam kāya samphassa paccayā uppajjati vedayitam pe tam pi anicca
translated: In this way, the body is impermanent, tactile objects are impermanent, body-consciousness is impermanent, body-contact is impermanent, and whatever feeling arises because of body-contact—whether pleasant, painful, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant—that too is impermanent.

analyzed: tiṭṭhatu tāva sotta
translated: Leave aside sleep.

original: Handāhaṁ idameva manasi karomi—🔽iti mano anicco, dhammā aniccā, manoviññāṇaṁ aniccaṁ, manosamphasso anicco, yampidaṁ
analyzed: handa aham idam eva manasi karomi  iti manaḥ aniccaḥ dhammāḥ aniccāḥ manaḥ viññāṇam anicca manaḥ samphassaḥ aniccaḥ
translated: I will just think about this:

original: manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tampi aniccaṁ”.
analyzed: manaḥ samphassa paccayā uppajjati vedayitam sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā tam pi anicca
translated: In this way, the mind is impermanent, thoughts are impermanent, mind-consciousness is impermanent, mind-contact is impermanent, and whatever feeling arises because of mind-contact—whether pleasant, painful, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant—that too is impermanent.”

original: Evaṁ passaṁ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati, rūpesupi nibbindati, cakkhuviññāṇepi nibbindati, cakkhusamphassepi nibbindati …pe…
analyzed: evam passa bhikkhave sutavā ariya sāvako cakkhusmim pi nibbindati rūpesu pi nibbindati cakkhu viññāṇe pi nibbindati cakkhu samphasse pi nibbindati pe
translated: Seeing this, the instructed noble disciple experiences revulsion towards the eye, forms, eye-consciousness, and eye-contact. …

original: yampidaṁ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tasmimpi nibbindati.🔽Nibbindaṁ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti.
analyzed: yam pi idam manaḥ samphassa paccayā uppajjati vedayitam sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā tasmim pi nibbindati  nibbindam virajjati virāgā vimuccati vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: He experiences revulsion towards whatever feeling arises with mind-contact as condition — whether pleasant, painful, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant.

original: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: Experiencing revulsion, he becomes dispassionate. Through dispassion, he is fully released. When he is fully released, he knows he is fully released. He understands that destroyed is birth, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being.”

analyzed: ayam kho bhikkhave ādittapariyāyaḥ dhammapariyāyaḥ ti
translated: This is the discourse on the burning, the discourse on the Dhamma.”

analyzed: aṭṭhama  sayutta nikāya
translated: The eighth.

analyzed: samuddavagga

analyzed: paṭhama hattha pāda upama sutta

original: “Hatthesu, bhikkhave, sati ādānanikkhepanaṁ paññāyati;🔽pādesu sati abhikkamapaṭikkamo paññāyati;
analyzed: hatthesu bhikkhave sati ādāna nikkhepanam paññāyati  pādesu sati abhikkama paṭikkamo paññāyati
translated: “When there are hands, monks, one sees a taking up and a putting down.🔽When there are feet, one sees going forwards and backwards.

analyzed: pabbesu sati samiñjana pasāraṇam paññāyati
translated: When there are the parts of the torso, one sees bending and stretching.

analyzed: kucchismim sati jighacchā pipāsā paññāyati

analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave cakkhusmim sati cakkhu samphassa paccayā uppajjati ajjhattam sukham dukkham pe

analyzed: jivhāya sati jivhā samphassa paccayā uppajjati ajjhattam sukham dukkham pe
translated: When there is the ear, pleasure and pain arise with ear-contact as condition. …

original: manasmiṁ sati manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhaṁ dukkhaṁ …pe….
analyzed: manasmin sati manaḥ samphassa paccayā uppajjati ajjhattam sukham dukkham pe

original: Hatthesu, bhikkhave, asati ādānanikkhepanaṁ na paññāyati;🔽pādesu asati abhikkamapaṭikkamo na paññāyati;
analyzed: hatthesu bhikkhave asati ādāna nikkhepanam na paññāyati  pādesu asati abhikkama paṭikkamaḥ na paññāyati
translated: “When there are no hands, placing and taking are not discerned.🔽When there are no feet, coming and going are not discerned.

analyzed: pabbesu asati samiñjana pasāraṇam na paññāyati
translated: When there are no hips, bearing loads is not discerned.

original: kucchismiṁ asati jighacchā pipāsā na paññāyati.🔽Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cakkhusmiṁ asati cakkhusamphassapaccayā nuppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhaṁ dukkhaṁ …pe…
analyzed: kucchismiṃ asati jighacchā pipāsā na paññāyati  evam eva kho bhikkhave cakkhusmiṃ asati cakkhu samphassa paccayā nuppajjati ajjhattam sukham dukkham pe
translated: When there is no belly, hunger and thirst are not discerned.🔽So too, bhikkhus, when there is no eye, pleasure and pain arise with eye-contact as condition. …🔽When there is no ear, pleasure and pain arise with ear-contact as condition. …

analyzed: jivhāya asati jivhā samphassa paccayā na uppajjati pe
translated: When there is no tongue, dependent on tongue-contact there is no …🔽

original: manasmiṁ asati manosamphassapaccayā nuppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhaṁ dukkhan”ti.
analyzed: manasmim asati manaḥ samphassa paccayā nuppajjati ajjhattam sukham dukkham
translated: If the mind doesn’t exist, from the cessation of the mind, would pleasure & pain arise internally?”

analyzed: navama  sayutta nikāya  samuddavagga

original: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cakkhusmiṁ asati cakkhusamphassapaccayā nuppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhaṁ dukkhaṁ …pe…
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave cakkhusmiṃ asati cakkhu samphassa paccayā nuppajjati ajjhattam sukham dukkham pe
translated: In the same way, when there is no eye, contact at the eye does not happen. With the cessation of contact at the eye, what is felt by mind and body that is felt by mind and body ceases and becomes extinct.

analyzed: jivhāya asati jivhā samphassa paccayā na uppajjati pe

analyzed: manasmim asati manaḥ samphassa paccayā nuppajjati ajjhattam sukham dukkham
translated: When there is no mind, contact at the mind does not happen. With the cessation of contact at the mind, what is felt by mind and body that is felt by mind and body ceases and becomes extinct.”

analyzed: āsīvisopamasutta
translated: The Chapter with Āsīvisa🔽The Simile of the Fourfold Venomous Snakes

analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave cattāro āsīvisāḥ ugga tejāḥ ghora visā
translated: “Monks, there are four venomous snakes.

original: Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhappaṭikūlo.
analyzed: atha purisaḥ āgaccheyya jīvitu kāmaḥ a maritu kāmaḥ sukha kāmaḥ dukkha ppaṭikūlo
translated: Then a person would come who wanted to live and not die, who wanted pleasure and recoiled from pain.

analyzed: tam enam evam vadeyyu
translated: They would say to him:

original: ‘ime te, ambho purisa, cattāro āsīvisā uggatejā ghoravisā kālena kālaṁ vuṭṭhāpetabbā, kālena kālaṁ nhāpetabbā, kālena kālaṁ bhojetabbā, kālena kālaṁ saṁvesetabbā.
analyzed: ime te ambho purisa cattāro āsīvisāḥ ugga tejāḥ ghora visā kālena kālam vuṭṭhāpetabbā kālena kālam nhāpetabbā kālena kālam bhojetabbā kālena kālam savesetabbā
translated: ‘Sir, these four snakes with supernormal powers and terrible poison must be taken out from time to time, bathed, fed, and put back again.

original: Yadā ca kho te, ambho purisa, imesaṁ catunnaṁ āsīvisānaṁ uggatejānaṁ ghoravisānaṁ🔽aññataro vā aññataro vā kuppissati, tato tvaṁ, ambho purisa, maraṇaṁ vā nigacchasi,
analyzed: yadā ca kho te ambho purisaḥ imesam catunnam āsīvisānam ugga tejānam ghora visāna  aññataraḥ vā aññataraḥ vā kuppissati tatas tva ambho purisa maraṇam vā nigacchasi
translated: ‘These four snakes, my good man, are very poisonous, with virulent poison. From time to time you must take them out, from time to time you must bathe them, from time to time you must feed them, and from time to time you must put them back.🔽And if you should fail to do any one of these things, my good man,

analyzed: maraṇa mattam vā
translated: then you will die or experience death-like suffering.

original: Yaṁ te, ambho purisa, karaṇīyaṁ taṁ karohī’ti.
analyzed: yam te ambho purisa karaṇīyam tam karohi iti
translated: So do what you have to do.’

original: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso bhīto catunnaṁ āsīvisānaṁ uggatejānaṁ ghoravisānaṁ yena vā tena vā palāyetha.
analyzed: atha kho saḥ bhikkhave purisaḥ bhīto catunnam āsīvisānam ugga tejānam ghora visānam yena vā tena vā palāyetha
translated: Then, monks, that man, being afraid of the four snakes, very poisonous, with virulent poison, would flee in whichever direction he could.

analyzed: tam enam evam vadeyyu
translated: And they would say to him:

original: ‘ime kho, ambho purisa, pañca vadhakā paccatthikā piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā, yattheva naṁ passissāma tattheva jīvitā voropessāmāti.
analyzed: ime kho ambho purisa pañca vadhakā paccatthikā piṭṭhitas piṭṭhitas anubandhā yattha eva nam passissāma tattha eva jīvitā voropessāma ati
translated: ‘These five murderers, my good man, are following right behind you, thinking, “Wherever we see him, right there we will kill him.”

original: Yaṁ te, ambho purisa, karaṇīyaṁ taṁ karohī’ti.
analyzed: yam te ambho purisa karaṇīyam tam karohi iti
translated: Do what you have to do.’

original: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso bhīto catunnaṁ āsīvisānaṁ uggatejānaṁ ghoravisānaṁ, bhīto pañcannaṁ vadhakānaṁ paccatthikānaṁ yena vā tena vā palāyetha.
analyzed: atha kho saḥ bhikkhave purisaḥ bhīto catunnam āsīvisānam ugga tejānam ghora visāna bhīto pañcannam vadhakānam paccatthikānam yena vā tena vā palāyetha
translated: Then that man, being afraid of the four snakes, would flee in whatever direction he could.

analyzed: tam enam evam vadeyyu
translated: And they would say to him:

original: ‘ayaṁ te, ambho purisa, chaṭṭho antaracaro vadhako ukkhittāsiko piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandho yattheva naṁ passissāmi tattheva siro pātessāmīti.
analyzed: ayam te ambho purisa chaṭṭhaḥ antara caraḥ vadhako ukkhitta asiko piṭṭhitaḥ piṭṭhitaḥ anubandho yatthā iva nam passissāmi tatthā iva siraḥ pātessāmi iti
translated: ‘This is your sixth pursuer, the one with the upraised sword. Wherever I see him, there I will cut off his head.

original: Yaṁ te, ambho purisa, karaṇīyaṁ taṁ karohī’ti.
analyzed: yam te ambho purisa karaṇīyam tam karohi iti
translated: Do what you have to do.’

original: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso bhīto catunnaṁ āsīvisānaṁ uggatejānaṁ ghoravisānaṁ,
analyzed: atha kho saḥ bhikkhave purisaḥ bhīto catunnam āsīvisānam ugga tejānam
translated: Then that man, being afraid of the four snakes,

original: bhīto pañcannaṁ vadhakānaṁ paccatthikānaṁ, bhīto chaṭṭhassa antaracarassa vadhakassa
analyzed: bhīto pañcannam vadhakānam paccatthikāna bhīto chaṭṭhassa antara carassa vadhakassa
translated: being afraid of the five assassins, being afraid of the sixth pursuer,

original: ukkhittāsikassa yena vā tena vā palāyetha.🔽So passeyya suññaṁ gāmaṁ.
analyzed: ukkhitta asikassa yena vā tena vā palāyetha 🔽so passeyya suññam gāma
translated: would flee in whatever direction he could.🔽He would see an empty village.

original: Yaññadeva gharaṁ paviseyya rittakaññeva paviseyya tucchakaññeva paviseyya suññakaññeva paviseyya.
analyzed: yaññat eva gharam paviseyya ritta kaññā iva paviseyya tuccha kaññā iva paviseyya suñña kaññā iva paviseyya
translated: Whatever house he entered, he entered it empty-handed, and he left it empty-handed.

original: Yaññadeva bhājanaṁ parimaseyya rittakaññeva parimaseyya tucchakaññeva parimaseyya suññakaññeva parimaseyya.🔽Tamenaṁ evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
analyzed: yaññat eva bhājanam parimaseyya ritta kaññā iva parimaseyya tuccha kaññā iva parimaseyya suñña kaññā iva parimaseyya  tam enam evam vadeyyu
translated: Whatever vessel he used, he used it empty and he put it away empty.

original: ‘idāni, ambho purisa, imaṁ suññaṁ gāmaṁ corā gāmaghātakā pavisanti.
analyzed: idāni ambho purisaḥ imam suññam gāmam corāḥ gāma ghātakā pavisanti
translated: And they would say to him, ‘Now, good man, the thieves, the village-destroyers, are entering this empty village.

original: Yaṁ te, ambho purisa, karaṇīyaṁ taṁ karohī’ti.
analyzed: yam te ambho purisa karaṇīyam tam karohi iti
translated: Do what you have to do.’

original: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso bhīto catunnaṁ āsīvisānaṁ uggatejānaṁ ghoravisānaṁ,
analyzed: atha kho saḥ bhikkhave purisaḥ bhīto catunnam āsīvisānam ugga tejānam
translated: “Then that man, being afraid of the four snakes with virulent poison,

original: bhīto pañcannaṁ vadhakānaṁ paccatthikānaṁ, bhīto chaṭṭhassa antaracarassa vadhakassa
analyzed: bhīto pañcannam vadhakānam paccatthikāna bhīto chaṭṭhassa antara carassa vadhakassa
translated: being afraid of the five executioners, his enemies, being afraid of the sixth executioner who lurks in ambush,

original: ukkhittāsikassa, bhīto corānaṁ gāmaghātakānaṁ yena vā tena vā palāyetha.
analyzed: ukkhitta āsikassa bhītaḥ corānam gāma ghātakānam yena vā tena vā palāyetha
translated: with drawn sword, being afraid of the thieves, the village-destroyers, would flee in whatever direction he could.

original: So passeyya mahantaṁ udakaṇṇavaṁ orimaṁ tīraṁ sāsaṅkaṁ sappaṭibhayaṁ, pārimaṁ tīraṁ khemaṁ appaṭibhayaṁ.
analyzed: so passeyya mahantam udakaṇṇavam orimam tīram sa āsaṅkam sa paṭibhaya pārimam tīram khemam appaṭibhaya
translated: He would see a great expanse of water, with the near shore fearful and dangerous and the further shore safe and free from danger,

original: Na cassa nāvā santāraṇī uttarasetu vā apārā pāraṁ gamanāya.
analyzed: na ca assa nāvā santāraṇī uttara setu vā apārā pāram gamanāya
translated: There is no boat or bridge to take him across to the other shore.

original: Atha kho, bhikkhave, tassa purisassa evamassa:
analyzed: atha kho bhikkhave tassa purisassa evamassa
translated: Then the man thinks:

original: ‘ayaṁ kho mahāudakaṇṇavo orimaṁ tīraṁ sāsaṅkaṁ sappaṭibhayaṁ, pārimaṁ tīraṁ khemaṁ appaṭibhayaṁ, natthi ca nāvā santāraṇī uttarasetu vā apārā pāraṁ gamanāya.
analyzed: ayam kho mahāudakaṇṇavaḥ orimam tīram sāsaṅkam sappaṭibhaya pārimam tīram khemam appaṭibhaya natthi ca nāvā santāraṇī uttara setu vā apārā pāram gamanāya
translated: ‘This great expanse of water has a near shore that is dangerous and fearful, and a further shore that is safe and free from danger, but there is no boat or bridge to take me across to the other shore.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṁ saṅkaḍḍhitvā kullaṁ bandhitvā taṁ kullaṁ nissāya hatthehi ca pādehi ca vāyamamāno sotthinā pāraṁ gaccheyyan’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham tiṇa kaṭṭha sākhā palāsam saṅkaḍḍhitvā kullam bandhitvā tam kullam nissāya hatthehi ca pādehi ca vāyamamānaḥ sotthinā pāram gaccheyyanti
translated: What if I were to collect grass, twigs, branches, and leaves and bind them together into a raft, and floating on that raft, making an effort with my hands and feet, reach the far shore safely?’

original: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṁ saṅkaḍḍhitvā kullaṁ bandhitvā
analyzed: atha kho saḥ bhikkhave purisaḥ tiṇa kaṭṭha sākhā palāsam saṅkaḍḍhitvā kullam bandhitvā
translated: Then the man collects grass, twigs, branches, and leaves, and binds them together into a raft,

original: taṁ kullaṁ nissāya hatthehi ca pādehi ca vāyamamāno sotthinā pāraṁ gaccheyya, tiṇṇo
analyzed: tam kullam nissāya hatthehi ca pādehi ca vāyamamānaḥ sotthinā pāram gaccheyya
translated: and floating on that raft, making an effort with his hands and feet, he reaches the far shore safely.

analyzed: pāraṅgataḥ thale tiṭṭhati brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: Having crossed over, having reached the far shore, he stands on high ground, a brahman.

original: Upamā kho myāyaṁ, bhikkhave, katā atthassa viññāpanāya.
analyzed: upamā kho myāya bhikkhave katā atthassa viññāpanāya
translated: I have given this simile in order to convey a meaning.

analyzed: ayam ca itthā atthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning:

original: cattāro āsīvisā uggatejā ghoravisāti kho, bhikkhave, catunnetaṁ mahābhūtānaṁ adhivacanaṁ—
analyzed: cattāro āsīvisāḥ ugga tejāḥ ghora visā ati kho bhikkhave catunna etam mahābhūtānam
translated: The four poisonous snakes with deadly venom are a figure for the four great elements:

analyzed: pathavī dhātuyā āpaḥ dhātuyā tejaḥ dhātuyā vāyo dhātuyā
translated: the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.

original: Pañca vadhakā paccatthikāti kho, bhikkhave, pañcannetaṁ upādānakkhandhānaṁ adhivacanaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: pañca vadhakā paccatthikā ati kho bhikkhave upādānakkhandhānam
translated: The five assassins are a figure for the five aggregates affected by clinging:

original: rūpupādānakkhandhassa, vedanupādānakkhandhassa, saññupādānakkhandhassa, saṅkhārupādānakkhandhassa, viññāṇupādānakkhandhassa.🔽Chaṭṭho antaracaro vadhako ukkhittāsikoti kho, bhikkhave, nandīrāgassetaṁ adhivacanaṁ.
analyzed: rūpa upādāna khandhassa vedanā upādāna khandhassa saññu pādāna khandhassa saṅkhāru pādāna khandhassa viññāṇu pādāna khandhassa  chaṭṭhaḥ antara caraḥ vadhakaḥ ukkhitta āsikaḥ ti kho bhikkhave nandīrāgassa itam adhivacana
translated: the material form aggregate affected by clinging, the feeling aggregate affected by clinging, the perception aggregate affected by clinging, the formations aggregate affected by clinging, and the consciousness aggregate affected by clinging.🔽The sixth assassin who lurks in the inner quarters with a drawn sword is a figure for joy and grief.

original: Suñño gāmoti kho, bhikkhave, channetaṁ ajjhattikānaṁ āyatanānaṁ adhivacanaṁ.
analyzed: suññaḥ gāmaḥ ti kho bhikkhave channa itam ajjhattikānam āyatanānam adhivacana
translated: The deserted village is a figure for the six internal sense spheres.

original: Cakkhuto cepi naṁ, bhikkhave, paṇḍito byatto medhāvī upaparikkhati rittakaññeva khāyati, tucchakaññeva khāyati, suññakaññeva khāyati …pe…
analyzed: cakkhutaḥ ce pi na bhikkhave paṇḍitaḥ byattaḥ medhāvī upaparikkhati ritta kaññā iva khāyati tuccha kaññā iva khāyati suñña kaññā iva khāyati pe
translated: If a wise, competent, intelligent person examines it, it appears empty, void, and hollow. …

analyzed: jivhāto ce pi na bhikkhave pe
translated: If a wise man, bhikkhus, examines the tongue …

original: manato cepi naṁ, bhikkhave, paṇḍito byatto medhāvī upaparikkhati rittakaññeva khāyati, tucchakaññeva khāyati, suññakaññeva khāyati.
analyzed: manataḥ ce pi na bhikkhave paṇḍitaḥ byattaḥ medhāvī upaparikkhati ritta kaññā iva khāyati tuccha kaññā iva khāyati suñña kaññā iva khāyati
translated: the mind, he sees that it is void, hollow, insubstantial.

original: Corā gāmaghātakāti kho, bhikkhave, channetaṁ bāhirānaṁ āyatanānaṁ adhivacanaṁ.
analyzed: corāḥ gāma ghātakāḥ ati kho bhikkhave channa itam bāhirānam āyatanānam adhivacana
translated: ‘Robbers who attack a village’ is a term for the six external bases.

original: Cakkhu, bhikkhave, haññati manāpāmanāpesu rūpesu;🔽sotaṁ, bhikkhave …pe…
analyzed: cakkhu bhikkhave haññati manāpa amanāpesu rūpesu  sota bhikkhave pe
translated: The eye, bhikkhus, is harmed by agreeable and disagreeable forms.🔽The ear is harmed by agreeable and disagreeable sounds.

analyzed: bhikkhave pe
translated: The nose is harmed by agreeable and disagreeable odours.

analyzed: jivhā bhikkhave haññati manāpa amanāpesu rasesu
translated: The tongue is harmed by agreeable and disagreeable tastes.

analyzed: kāyaḥ bhikkhave pe
translated: The body is harmed by agreeable and disagreeable tactile objects.

analyzed: manaḥ bhikkhave haññati manāpa amanāpesu dhammesu
translated: The mind is harmed by agreeable and disagreeable ideas.

original: Mahā udakaṇṇavoti kho, bhikkhave, catunnetaṁ oghānaṁ adhivacanaṁ—🔽kāmoghassa, bhavoghassa, diṭṭhoghassa, avijjoghassa.
analyzed: kho bhikkhave oghānam  kāma oghassa bhava oghassa diṭṭha oghassa avijja oghassa
translated: ‘A great flood of water’ is a term for the four floods:🔽the flood of sensuality, the flood of existence, the flood of views, and the flood of ignorance.

original: Orimaṁ tīraṁ sāsaṅkaṁ sappaṭibhayanti kho, bhikkhave, sakkāyassetaṁ adhivacanaṁ.
analyzed: orimam tīram sa āsaṅkam sa paṭibhayanti kho bhikkhave sa kāyassa itam adhivacana
translated: ‘This shore is fearful and full of terrors’ is a term for this self.

original: Pārimaṁ tīraṁ khemaṁ appaṭibhayanti kho, bhikkhave, nibbānassetaṁ adhivacanaṁ.🔽Kullanti kho, bhikkhave, ariyassetaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa adhivacanaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: pārimam tīram khemam appaṭibhayanti kho bhikkhave nibbānassa etam adhivacana  kullanti kho bhikkhave ariyassa etam aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa adhivacana
translated: ‘The other shore, which is safe and free from danger’ is a designation for Nibbāna.

analyzed: sammā diṭṭhi pe sammā samādhi
translated: ‘The raft’ is a designation for the noble eightfold path, that is, right view, right resolve, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.

original: Tassa hatthehi ca pādehi ca vāyāmoti kho, bhikkhave, vīriyārambhassetaṁ adhivacanaṁ.
analyzed: tassa hatthehi ca pādehi ca vāyāmaḥ iti kho bhikkhave vīriya ārambhassa etam adhivacana
translated: ‘Striving with his hands and feet’ is a designation for the arousing of energy.

original: Tiṇṇo pāraṅgato thale tiṭṭhati brāhmaṇoti kho, bhikkhave, arahato etaṁ adhivacanan”ti.🔽Paṭhamaṁ.
analyzed: tiṇṇaḥ pāraṅgataḥ thale tiṭṭhati brāhmaṇaḥ iti kho bhikkhave arahataḥ etam adhivacanam ti  paṭhama
translated: ‘Having crossed over, the brahmin stands on high ground’ is a designation for the arahant.”🔽The first section for recitation on the raft is finished.

analyzed: sayutta nikāya
translated: The Connected Discourses with Devadatta,

analyzed: āsīvisavagga
translated: The Chapter on the Snake

analyzed: rathopamasutta
translated: The Simile of the Chariot

original: “Tīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu diṭṭheva dhamme sukhasomanassabahulo viharati, yoni cassa āraddhā hoti āsavānaṁ khayāya.
analyzed: tīhi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu diṭṭhe iva dhamme sukha somanassa bahulaḥ viharati yoni ca ssa āraddhā hoti āsavānam khayāya
translated: “Bhikkhus, a bhikkhu endowed with three qualities dwells much in suffering in this very life—with distress, anguish, and fever—and he does not fulfill the true way, the Dhamma that is wholesome.

analyzed: katamehi tīhi
translated: What three?

original: Indriyesu guttadvāro hoti, bhojane mattaññū, jāgariyaṁ anuyutto.
analyzed: indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ hoti bhojane mattaññū jāgariyam anuyuttaḥ
translated: He is not guarded in the doors of the sense faculties, he is immoderate in eating, and he is not devoted to wakefulness.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ hoti
translated: “And how, bhikkhus, is a bhikkhu not guarded in the doors of the sense faculties?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti, nānubyañjanaggāhī;
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam disvā na nimitta ggāhī hoti na anubyañjana ggāhī
translated: There is the case where a monk, on seeing a form via the eye, doesn’t grasp at any theme or variations by which — as one who grasps —

original: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: yatvā adhikaraṇam enam cakkhu indriyam asavutam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: malice, unskillful qualities born of malice, would increase.

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ. Tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati; rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ; cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya paṭipajjati rakkhati cakkhu indriya cakkhu indriye savaram āpajjati
translated: He practices with restraint, guarding the eye faculty, and attaining equanimity with regard to the eye faculty.

analyzed: sotena saddam sutvā  ghānena gandham ghāyitvā
translated: On hearing a sound via the ear…🔽On smelling an odor via the nose…

analyzed: jivhāya rasam sāyitvā
translated: On tasting a flavor via the tongue…

analyzed: kāyena phoṭṭhabbam phusitvā
translated: On touching a tactile sensation via the body…

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī;
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya na nimitta ggāhī hoti na anubyañjana ggāhī
translated: On cognizing an idea via the intellect, he doesn’t grasp at any theme or variations by which — as one who grasps —

original: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: yatvā adhikaraṇam enam man indriyam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: malice, unskillful qualities born of malice, would increase.

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati; rakkhati manindriyaṁ; manindriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya paṭipajjati rakkhati manindriya manindriye savaram āpajjati
translated: He practices with restraint, guarding the intellect faculty, and attaining equanimity with regard to the intellect faculty.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, subhūmiyaṁ cātumahāpathe ājaññaratho yutto assa ṭhito odhastapatodo.🔽Tamenaṁ dakkho yoggācariyo assadammasārathi abhiruhitvā vāmena hatthena rasmiyo gahetvā,
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave subhūmiyam cātumahāpathe ājaññarathaḥ yuttaḥ assa ṭhitaḥ  tam enam dakkhaḥ yogga ācariyaḥ assa damma sārathi abhiruhitvā vāmena hatthena rasmiyaḥ gahetvā
translated: It’s just as if there were a carriage standing at a crossroads with a goad lying nearby.

original: dakkhiṇena hatthena patodaṁ gahetvā, yenicchakaṁ yadicchakaṁ sāreyyapi paccāsāreyyapi.🔽Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imesaṁ channaṁ indriyānaṁ ārakkhāya sikkhati, saṁyamāya sikkhati, damāya sikkhati, upasamāya sikkhati.
analyzed: dakkhiṇena hatthena patodam gahetvā yenicchakam yadicchakam sāreyya api paccāsāreyya api  evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu imesam channam indriyānaṃ ārakkhāya sikkhati sayamāya sikkhati damāya sikkhati upasamāya sikkhati
translated: A skilled driver or groom would mount it, holding the reins in his left hand and the goad in his right, and he could drive it wherever he wanted without hindrance.🔽In the same way, a monk trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe in sensitive to the mind.’ He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe out sensitive to the mind.’🔽He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe in satisfying the mind.’ He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe out satisfying the mind.’🔽He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe in steadying the mind.’ He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe out steadying the mind.’

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ hoti
translated: He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe in releasing the mind.’ He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe out releasing the mind.’🔽He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe in calming the mind.’ He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe out calming the mind.’🔽He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe in focusing on inconstancy.’ He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe out focusing on inconstancy.’🔽He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe in focusing on dispassion.’ He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe out focusing on dispassion.’🔽He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe in focusing on cessation.’ He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe out focusing on cessation.’🔽He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe in focusing on letting go.’ He trains himself, thinking: ‘I will breathe out focusing on letting go.’🔽That’s how a monk is inwardly sensitive to the mind and to mental qualities.
