original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bhojane mattaññū hoti?🔽Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso āhāraṁ āhāreti:
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu bhojane mattaññū hoti  idha bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisas āhāram āhāreti
translated: “And how is a monk moderate in eating?

original: ‘neva davāya, na madāya, na maṇḍanāya, na vibhūsanāya, yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā,
analyzed: na iva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya yāvat eva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā
translated: There is the case where a monk, reflecting appropriately, takes food neither for amusement nor for intoxication nor for the sake of physical beauty and attractiveness, but only for the endurance and continuance of this body, for ending discomfort, and for assisting the holy life, considering: ‘Thus I shall terminate old feelings without arousing new feelings and I will be healthy and blameless and will live in comfort.’

original: yāpanāya, vihiṁsūparatiyā, brahmacariyānuggahāya, iti purāṇañca vedanaṁ paṭihaṅkhāmi,
analyzed: yāpanāya brahmacariya anuggahāya iti purāṇam ca vedanam paṭihaṅkhāmi
translated: for the support of those who are sick, for the assistance of the bhikkhus, for the performance of the duties of the Saṅgha, for the purpose of avoiding trouble, for the purpose of guarding against criticism.

original: navañca vedanaṁ na uppādessāmi, yātrā ca me bhavissati, anavajjatā ca phāsuvihāro cā’ti.
analyzed: navam ca vedanam na uppādessāmi yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajja tā ca phāsu vihāraḥ ca ati
translated: Thus I will remove old feelings and not give rise to new feelings. I will maintain myself in comfort and not neglect the higher mind.”

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso vaṇaṁ ālimpeyya yāvadeva rohanatthāya, seyyathā vā pana akkhaṁ abbhañjeyya yāvadeva bhārassa nittharaṇatthāya;
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave purisaḥ vaṇam ālimpeyya yāvat eva rohana atthāya seyyathā vā pana akkham abbhañjeyya yāvat eva bhārassa nittharaṇa tthāya
translated: Just as a man might apply ointment to a wound only in order to heal it, or just as a man might oil an axle only in order to carry a load,

original: evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso āhāraṁ āhāreti:🔽‘neva davāya, na madāya, na maṇḍanāya, na vibhūsanāya, yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā,🔽yāpanāya, vihiṁsūparatiyā, brahmacariyānuggahāya, iti purāṇañca vedanaṁ paṭihaṅkhāmi,
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisas āhāram āhāreti  na iva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya yāvat eva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā  yāpanāya brahmacariya anuggahāya iti purāṇam ca vedanam paṭihaṅkhāmi
translated: so a bhikkhu should consume food reflecting wisely:

original: navañca vedanaṁ na uppādessāmi, yātrā ca me bhavissati, anavajjatā ca phāsuvihāro cā’ti.
analyzed: navam ca vedanam na uppādessāmi yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajja tā ca phāsu vihāraḥ ca ati
translated: ‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to maintain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual life, thinking: “Thus will I destroy old feelings and not give rise to new feelings. I will maintain myself, be blameless, and live in comfort.”

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bhojane mattaññū hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu bhojane mattaññū hoti
translated: This is how a bhikkhu is moderate in eating.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu jāgariyaṁ anuyutto hoti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu jāgariyam anuyuttaḥ hoti
translated: “And how is a monk devoted to wakefulness?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu divasaṁ caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu divasam caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittam parisodheti
translated: Here, during the day while walking back and forth and sitting, a monk purifies his mind of obstructive qualities.

original: Rattiyā paṭhamaṁ yāmaṁ caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: rattiyā paṭhamam yāmam caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittam parisodheti
translated: In the first watch of the night while walking back and forth and sitting, he purifies his mind of obstructive qualities.

original: Rattiyā majjhimaṁ yāmaṁ dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṁ kappeti pāde pādaṁ accādhāya sato sampajāno uṭṭhānasaññaṁ manasi karitvā.
analyzed: rattiyāḥ majjhimam yāmam dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyam kappeti pāde pādam accādhāya sataḥ sampajānaḥ uṭṭhāna saññam manasi karitvā
translated: In the middle watch of the night he lies down on the right side in the lion’s posture with one foot overlapping the other, mindful and fully aware, after noting in his mind the time for rising.

original: Rattiyā pacchimaṁ yāmaṁ paccuṭṭhāya caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: rattiyā pacchimam yāmam paccuṭṭhāya caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittam parisodheti
translated: After rising, in the third watch of the night while walking back and forth and sitting, he purifies his mind of obstructive qualities.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu jāgariyaṁ anuyutto hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu jāgariyam anuyuttaḥ hoti
translated: This is how a monk is devoted to wakefulness.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu diṭṭheva dhamme sukhasomanassabahulo viharati, yoni cassa āraddhā hoti āsavānaṁ khayāyā”ti.🔽Dutiyaṁ.
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave tīhi dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu diṭṭhe iva dhamme sukha somanassa bahulaḥ viharati yoni ca ssa āraddhā hoti āsavānam khayāya ati  dutiya
translated: “A monk endowed with these three qualities lives in comfort in the here and now and with the destruction of the taints enters and dwells in the deathless.”🔽The second section on the one who has one quality, etc.

analyzed: sayutta nikāya
translated: The Connected Discourses with Māra,🔽The second section on the one who has one quality, etc.

analyzed: āsīvisavagga
translated: 19. The Group on Snakes

original: Kummopamasutta🔽“Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhikkhave, kummo kacchapo sāyanhasamayaṁ anunadītīre gocarapasuto ahosi.
analyzed: kumma upama sutta  bhūta pubba bhikkhave kummaḥ kacchapo sāyanha samayam anu nadī tīre gocara pasutaḥ ahosi
translated: 19. The group on snakes 🔽The simile of the turtle 🔽“Once upon a time, monks, in the evening a turtle was wandering for food on the bank of the river Anomā.

original: Siṅgālopi kho, bhikkhave, sāyanhasamayaṁ anunadītīre gocarapasuto ahosi.
analyzed: siṅgālaḥ api kho bhikkhave sāyanha samayam anu nadī tīre gocara pasutaḥ ahosi
translated: A jackal, too, was wandering for food on the bank of the river Anomā in the evening.

original: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, kummo kacchapo siṅgālaṁ dūratova gocarapasutaṁ.
analyzed: addasā kho bhikkhave kummaḥ kacchapaḥ siṅgālam dūratas iva gocara pasuta
translated: The turtle saw the jackal wandering for food in the distance.

original: Disvāna soṇḍipañcamāni aṅgāni sake kapāle samodahitvā appossukko tuṇhībhūto saṅkasāyati.
analyzed: disvāna soṇḍi pañcamāni aṅgāni sake kapāle samodahitvā appa ussukkaḥ tuṇhībhūtaḥ saṅkasāyati
translated: Having seen him, he withdrew his four limbs and his head into his shell, and remained still and silent.

original: Siṅgālopi kho, bhikkhave, addasa kummaṁ kacchapaṁ dūratova gocarapasutaṁ.
analyzed: siṅgālaḥ api kho bhikkhave addasa kummam kacchapam dūratas iva gocara pasuta
translated: The jackal saw the turtle withdrawing his four limbs and his head into his shell in the distance.

original: Disvāna yena kummo kacchapo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā kummaṁ kacchapaṁ paccupaṭṭhito ahosi:
analyzed: disvāna yena kummaḥ kacchapo tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā kummam kacchapam paccupaṭṭhitaḥ ahosi
translated: Having seen him, he approached the turtle and stood in front of him, thinking:

original: ‘yadāyaṁ kummo kacchapo soṇḍipañcamānaṁ aṅgānaṁ aññataraṁ vā aññataraṁ vā aṅgaṁ abhininnāmessati, tattheva naṁ gahetvā uddālitvā khādissāmī’ti.
analyzed: yadā ayam kummaḥ kacchapaḥ soṇḍi pañcamānam aṅgānam aññataram vā aññataram vā aṅgam abhininnāmessati tattha iva nam gahetvā uddālitvā khādissāmi iti
translated: ‘Whenever this turtle extends one of his limbs, I’ll grab him, lift him up, and eat him.’

original: Yadā kho, bhikkhave, kummo kacchapo soṇḍipañcamānaṁ aṅgānaṁ aññataraṁ vā aññataraṁ vā aṅgaṁ na abhininnāmi, atha siṅgālo kummamhā nibbijja pakkāmi, otāraṁ alabhamāno.
analyzed: yadā kho bhikkhave kummaḥ kacchapaḥ soṇḍi pañcamānam aṅgānam aññataram vā aññataram vā aṅgam na abhininnāmi atha siṅgālaḥ kummamhā nibbijja pakkāmi otāram a labhamānaḥ
translated: When the turtle did not put out any of its limbs or its head, the jackal lost interest in it and went away, unable to find an opportunity.

original: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, tumhepi māro pāpimā satataṁ samitaṁ paccupaṭṭhito:
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave tumhe pi māraḥ pāpimā satatam samitam paccupaṭṭhitaḥ
translated: In the same way, monks, the Wicked One is constantly and continually intent on finding an opportunity to tempt you, thinking:

original: ‘appeva nāmāhaṁ imesaṁ cakkhuto vā otāraṁ labheyyaṁ …pe…🔽jivhāto vā otāraṁ labheyyaṁ …pe…
analyzed: appā iva nāma aham imesam cakkhutaḥ vā otāram labheyyam pe  jivhātaḥ vai otāram labheyyam pe
translated: ‘Perhaps I can find an opportunity in them through the eye, through the ear,

analyzed: vai otāram
translated: through the nose, through the tongue, through the body, or through the mind.’

analyzed: tasmā ati ha bhikkhave indriyesu gutta dvārāḥ viharatha
translated: Therefore, monks, you should live with guarded sense faculties.

original: Cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā mā nimittaggāhino ahuvattha, mā anubyañjanaggāhino.🔽Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: cakkhunā rūpam disvā mā nimitta ggāhinaḥ ahuvattha mā anubyañjana ggāhinaḥ  yatvā adhikaraṇam enam cakkhu indriyam asavutam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: On seeing a form with the eye, do not grasp at its signs and features.

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjatha, rakkhatha cakkhundriyaṁ, cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjatha.
analyzed: dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya paṭipajjatha rakkhatha cakkhundriya cakkhundriye savaram āpajjatha
translated: Since, if you were to leave the eye faculty unguarded, evil unwholesome states of longing and dejection might invade you, practice the way of its restraint, guard the eye faculty, undertake the restraint of the eye faculty.

analyzed: sotena saddam sutvā  ghānena gandham ghāyitvā
translated: Having heard a sound with the ear …🔽Having smelled an odor with the nose …

analyzed: jivhāya rasam sāyitvā
translated: Having tasted a taste with the tongue …

analyzed: kāyena phoṭṭhabbam phusitvā
translated: Having felt a tactile object with the body …

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya mā nimittaggāhino ahuvattha, mā anubyañjanaggāhino.
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya mā nimitta ggāhinaḥ ahuvattha mā anubyañjana ggāhinaḥ
translated: Having cognized a mental phenomenon with the mind, don’t grasp at its general appearance or its particulars.

original: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: yatvā adhikaraṇam enam man indriyam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: If you live with the mind faculty unrestrained, evil unskillful qualities — greed & distress — might invade you.

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjatha, rakkhatha manindriyaṁ, manindriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjatha.
analyzed: dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya paṭipajjatha rakkhatha manindriya manindriye savaram āpajjatha
translated: For that reason, practice restraint, protect the mind faculty, and undertake the restraint of the mind faculty.

original: Yato tumhe, bhikkhave, indriyesu guttadvārā viharissatha, atha tumhehipi māro pāpimā nibbijja pakkamissati, otāraṁ alabhamāno—
analyzed: yatas tumhe bhikkhave indriyesu gutta dvārāḥ viharissatha atha tumhehi pi māraḥ pāpimā nibbijja pakkamissati otāram a labhamānaḥ
translated: When you live with the faculties restrained, then Māra the Evil One — not finding an opening among you — will leave disappointed,

analyzed: siṅgālā iti  aṅgāni sake kapāle
translated: like a mustard seed on the point of an awl.🔽Like a tortoise, a monk should withdraw his limbs,

analyzed: samodaham bhikkhu manaḥ vitakke
translated: burning up thoughts in his own skull.

analyzed: a nissitaḥ aññam aheṭhayāno
translated: Not depending, not harming another,

analyzed: parinibbutaḥ nu upavadeyya kañci iti
translated: fully extinguished, he would not blame anyone.

analyzed: tatiya
translated: The third.

analyzed: sayutta nikāya
translated: Saṁyutta Nikāya 35.135–144

analyzed: āsīvisavagga
translated: The Chapter with Āsīvisa Sutta
The Simile of the Log (1)

original: Ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kosambiyaṁ viharati gaṅgāya nadiyā tīre.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā kosambiyam viharati gaṅgāya nadiyā tīre
translated: One time the Lord was staying at Kosambi, on the bank of the Ganges.

original: Addasā kho bhagavā mahantaṁ dārukkhandhaṁ gaṅgāya nadiyā sotena vuyhamānaṁ.
analyzed: addasā kho bhagavā mahantam dāru kkhandham gaṅgāya nadiyā sotena vuyhamāna
translated: And the Lord saw a great log being carried away by the current of the Ganges,

analyzed: disvāna bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: and on seeing it he addressed the monks, saying:

original: “passatha no tumhe, bhikkhave, amuṁ mahantaṁ dārukkhandhaṁ gaṅgāya nadiyā sotena vuyhamānan”ti?
analyzed: passatha no tumhe bhikkhave amum mahantam dāru kkhandham gaṅgāya nadiyā sotena vuyhamānanti
translated: “Do you see, monks, that great log being carried away by the current of the Ganges?”

analyzed: eva bhante
translated: “Yes, Lord.”

original: “Sace so, bhikkhave, dārukkhandho na orimaṁ tīraṁ upagacchati, na pārimaṁ tīraṁ upagacchati,
analyzed: sace saḥ bhikkhave dāru kkhandhaḥ na orimam tīram upagacchati na pārimam tīram upagacchati
translated: “If, monks, that log does not go to the near shore, nor to the further shore,

original: na majjhe saṁsīdissati, na thale ussīdissati, na manussaggāho gahessati, na amanussaggāho
analyzed: na majjhe sasīdissati na thale ussīdissati na manussa gāho gahessati na a manussa gāho
translated: nor get stranded on dry land, nor get cast up on the bank, nor get taken by human beings, nor get taken by non-human beings,

original: gahessati, na āvaṭṭaggāho gahessati, na antopūti bhavissati;
analyzed: gahessati na āvaṭṭaggāhaḥ gahessati na antopūti bhavissati
translated: nor get taken by any creature in the water, nor get lost inside a whirlpool, nor rot away inside,

original: evañhi so, bhikkhave, dārukkhandho samuddaninno bhavissati samuddapoṇo samuddapabbhāro.
analyzed: evam hi saḥ bhikkhave dāru kkhandhaḥ samudda ninnaḥ bhavissati samudda poṇaḥ samudda pabbhāro
translated: then that log, monks, will go to the ocean, will tend to the ocean, will incline to the ocean.

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: And why is that?

original: Samuddaninno, bhikkhave, gaṅgāya nadiyā soto samuddapoṇo samuddapabbhāro.
analyzed: samudda ninnaḥ bhikkhave gaṅgāya nadiyā sotaḥ samudda poṇaḥ samudda pabbhāro
translated: The flow of the Ganges River tends, slopes, and inclines to the ocean.

original: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, sace tumhepi na orimaṁ tīraṁ upagacchatha, na pārimaṁ tīraṁ upagacchatha;
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave sace tumhe api na orimam tīram upagacchatha na pārimam tīram upagacchatha
translated: So too, bhikkhus, if you do not approach the near shore, do not approach the far shore,

original: na majjhe saṁsīdissatha, na thale ussīdissatha, na manussaggāho gahessati, na amanussaggāho gahessati, na āvaṭṭaggāho gahessati, na antopūtī bhavissatha;
analyzed: na majjhe sasīdissatha na thale ussīdissatha na manussa ggāhaḥ gahessati na amanussa ggāhaḥ gahessati na āvaṭṭa ggāhaḥ gahessati na antopūtī bhavissatha
translated: do not sink in the middle, do not get cast up on high ground, do not get seized by human beings, do not get seized by non-human beings, do not get caught in a maelstrom, do not get broken up by waves, do not get destroyed by sea monsters,

original: evaṁ tumhe, bhikkhave, nibbānaninnā bhavissatha nibbānapoṇā nibbānapabbhārā.
analyzed: evam tumhe bhikkhave nibbāna ninnāḥ bhavissatha nibbāna poṇāḥ nibbāna pabbhārāḥ
translated: then you will tend, slope, and incline to nibbana.

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: nibbāna ninnā bhikkhave sammādiṭṭhi nibbāna poṇā nibbāna pabbhārā ti
translated: Right view tends, slopes, and inclines to nibbana.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte aññataraḥ bhikkhu bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, a certain bhikkhu said to the Blessed One:🔽“But, venerable sir, how does the one who has gone forth abide?”

original: “kiṁ nu kho, bhante, orimaṁ tīraṁ, kiṁ pārimaṁ tīraṁ, ko majjhe saṁsādo, ko thale ussādo, ko manussaggāho, ko amanussaggāho, ko āvaṭṭaggāho, ko antopūtibhāvo”ti?
analyzed: kim nu kho bhante orimam tīra kim pārimam tīra kaḥ majjhe sasādaḥ kaḥ thale ussādaḥ kaḥ manussa ggāho kaḥ amanussa ggāho kaḥ āvaṭṭa ggāho kaḥ antopūtibhāvaḥ ti
translated: “What, Venerable Sir, is this side? What is the other side? What is getting swept away in the middle? What is getting stranded on high ground? What is a human thief? What is a non-human thief? What is a whirlpool? What is rotting from within?”🔽

original: “‘Orimaṁ tīran’ti kho, bhikkhu, channetaṁ ajjhattikānaṁ āyatanānaṁ adhivacanaṁ.
analyzed: orimam tīran ti kho bhikkhu channa itam ajjhattikānam āyatanānam adhivacana
translated: “What, Venerable Sir, is this side? What is the other side? What is getting swept away in the middle? What is getting stranded on high ground? What is the human crocodile? What is the non-human crocodile? What is the whirlpool? What is rotting inside?”🔽“‘This side’ is a term for the six internal sense-spheres.

original: ‘Pārimaṁ tīran’ti kho, bhikkhu, channetaṁ bāhirānaṁ āyatanānaṁ adhivacanaṁ.🔽‘Majjhe saṁsādo’ti kho, bhikkhu, nandīrāgassetaṁ adhivacanaṁ.
analyzed: pārimam kho bhikkhu channa itam bāhirānam āyatanānam adhivacana  majjhe sasādo ti kho bhikkhu nandī rāgassa itam
translated: ‘The other side’ is a term for the six external sense-spheres.🔽‘Getting swept away in the middle’ is a term for delight and lust.

analyzed: thale ussādaḥ ti kho bhikkhu asmimānassa etam
translated: ‘Getting stranded on high ground’ is a term for the conceit ‘I am’.

analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhu manussaggāho
translated: “And what, monk, is the human crocodile?🔽Here, a monk lives in close association with householders,

original: Idha, bhikkhu, gihīhi saṁsaṭṭho viharati, sahanandī sahasokī, sukhitesu sukhito, dukkhitesu dukkhito, uppannesu kiccakaraṇīyesu attanā tesu yogaṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: idha bhikkhu gihīhi sasaṭṭhaḥ viharati saha nandī saha sokī sukhitesu sukhitaḥ dukkhitesu dukkhitaḥ uppannesu kicca karaṇīyesu attanā tesu yogam āpajjati
translated: and he is happy with them, rejoices with them, and engages in activities with them.

analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhu manussaggāho
translated: This is called the human crocodile.

analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhu a manussa ggāho
translated: “And what, bhikkhu, is the human-nonhuman obsession?

original: Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco aññataraṁ devanikāyaṁ paṇidhāya brahmacariyaṁ carati: ‘imināhaṁ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhu ekaccaḥ aññataram devanikāyam paṇidhāya brahmacariyam carati iminā aham sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devaḥ vā bhavissāmi devaññataraḥ vā ati
translated: Here someone leads the holy life longing for the heavenly world: ‘By this virtue or practice or austerity or holy life, may I become a great deity or some lesser deity.’

analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhu a manussa ggāhaḥ
translated: This is called the human-nonhuman obsession.

analyzed: āvaṭṭaggāho ti kho bhikkhu pañcannaṃ etam kāmaguṇānaṃ
translated: ‘The obsession of the round’ is a term for the five cords of sensual pleasure.

analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhu antopūtibhāvaḥ
translated: “And what, bhikkhu, is the state of internal corruption?

original: Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco dussīlo hoti pāpadhammo asucisaṅkassarasamācāro paṭicchannakammanto assamaṇo samaṇapaṭiñño abrahmacārī brahmacāripaṭiñño antopūti avassuto kasambujāto.
analyzed: idha bhikkhu ekaccaḥ dussīlaḥ hoti pāpa dhammaḥ asuci saṅkassara samācāraḥ paṭicchanna kammantaḥ a ssamaṇaḥ samaṇa paṭiññaḥ abrahmacārī brahmacāri paṭiññaḥ antopūti avassutaḥ kasambu jātaḥ
translated: Here someone is unvirtuous, of bad character, impure and suspect in his undertakings, secretive about his evil conduct, not an ascetic though professing to be one, not a celibate though professing to be one, inwardly rotten, corrupt, and putrid, lecherous though professing not to be so.

analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhu antopūtibhāvo ti
translated: This is called the state of internal corruption.”

original: Tena kho pana samayena nando gopālako bhagavato avidūre ṭhito hoti.
analyzed: tena khalu pana samayena nandaḥ gopālakaḥ bhagavataḥ avidūre ṭhitaḥ hoti
translated: Now on that occasion the cowherd Nanda was standing not far from the Blessed One,

original: Atha kho nando gopālako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu nandaḥ gopālakaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then the cowherd Nanda said to the Blessed One:

original: “ahaṁ kho, bhante, na orimaṁ tīraṁ upagacchāmi, na pārimaṁ tīraṁ upagacchāmi, na🔽majjhe saṁsīdissāmi, na thale ussīdissāmi, na maṁ manussaggāho gahessati, na amanussaggāho
analyzed: aham kho bhante na orimam tīram upagacchāmi na pārimam tīram upagacchāmi na  majjhe sasīdissāmi na thale ussīdissāmi na mama manussa gāhaḥ gahessati na a manussa gāhaḥ
translated: “I won’t go to this shore, I won’t go to the other shore,

original: gahessati, na āvaṭṭaggāho gahessati, na antopūti bhavissāmi.
analyzed: gahessati na āvaṭṭaggāhaḥ gahessati na antopūti bhavissāmi
translated: I won’t sink in the middle, I won’t be stranded on the bank, I won’t be carried away by the stream, I won’t die in the water, and I won’t be lost to the cows.

original: Labheyyāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, labheyyaṁ upasampadan”ti.
analyzed: labheyya āha bhante bhagavato santike pabbajja labheyyam upasampadanti
translated: May I receive the going forth in the Buddha’s presence? May I receive the full ordination?”

original: “Tena hi tvaṁ, nanda, sāmikānaṁ gāvo niyyātehī”ti.
analyzed: tena hi tva nanda gāvaḥ
translated: “Well then, Nanda, return the cows to their owners.”

analyzed: gamissanti bhante gāvaḥ
translated: “They’ll go, Sir, for they’re eager for their calves.”

analyzed: tva nanda sāmikānam gāvā iti
translated: “You must return the cows to their owners.”

original: Atha kho nando gopālako sāmikānaṁ gāvo niyyātetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu nandaḥ gopālakaḥ sāmikānam gāvaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Nanda then returned the cows to their owners and went to the Buddha. He said,

analyzed: niyyātitāḥ bhante sāmikānam gāvaḥ
translated: “Sir, I’ve returned the cows to their owners.

original: Labheyyāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, labheyyaṁ upasampadan”ti.
analyzed: labheyya āha bhante bhagavato santike pabbajja labheyyam upasampadanti
translated: May I receive the going forth in the Buddha’s presence? May I receive the full ordination?”

original: Alattha kho nando gopālako bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, alattha upasampadaṁ.🔽Acirūpasampanno ca panāyasmā nando eko vūpakaṭṭho …pe…
analyzed: alattha kho nandaḥ gopālakaḥ bhagavato santike pabbajja alattha upasampada  acira upasampanno ca pana āyasmā nandaḥ ekaḥ vūpakaṭṭhaḥ pe
translated: And the cowherd Nanda received the going forth, received full ordination, in the presence of the Blessed One.🔽Not long after his full ordination, dwelling alone, withdrawn, diligent, ardent, & resolute, the venerable Nanda, by realizing it for himself with direct knowledge, in this very life entered & remained in that supreme goal of the holy life for the sake of which clansmen rightly go forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: aññataro ca panāyasmā nando arahataṁ ahosīti.🔽Catutthaṁ.
analyzed: aññataro ca pana ayasmai nandaḥ arahatam ahosi iti  catuttha
translated: And the venerable Nanda became another one of the arahants.🔽The fourth section on Nanda is finished.🔽The Connected Discourses with Nanda are finished.

analyzed: sayutta nikāya  āsīvisavagga
translated: The Connected Discourses with Devadatta
The Dārukkhandha Simile, the Second

original: Ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kimilāyaṁ viharati gaṅgāya nadiyā tīre.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā kim ilāyam viharati gaṅgāya nadiyā tīre
translated: One time the Blessed One was staying at Kimibilā on the bank of the Ganges River.

original: Addasā kho bhagavā mahantaṁ dārukkhandhaṁ gaṅgāya nadiyā sotena vuyhamānaṁ.
analyzed: addasā kho bhagavā mahantam dāru kkhandham gaṅgāya nadiyā sotena vuyhamāna
translated: The Blessed One saw a great log being carried away by the current of the Ganges River.

analyzed: disvāna bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: Having seen it, he addressed the monks,

original: “passatha no tumhe, bhikkhave, amuṁ mahantaṁ dārukkhandhaṁ gaṅgāya nadiyā sotena vuyhamānan”ti?
analyzed: passatha no tumhe bhikkhave amum mahantam dāru kkhandham gaṅgāya nadiyā sotena vuyhamānanti
translated: “Monks, do you see that great log being carried away by the current of the Ganges River?”

analyzed: eva bhante pe
translated: “Yes, lord.” …

original: evaṁ vutte, āyasmā kimilo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte āyasmā kimilaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, Ven. Kimbila said to the Blessed One,

analyzed: kim nu khalu bhante orimam tīram pe
translated: “Lord, what is the near shore? What is the far shore?

analyzed: katamaḥ ca antopūtibhāvaḥ
translated: “And what, Kimbila, is internal corruption?

original: Idha, kimila, bhikkhu aññataraṁ saṅkiliṭṭhaṁ āpattiṁ āpanno hoti yathārūpāya āpattiyā na vuṭṭhānaṁ paññāyati.
analyzed: idha kimila bhikkhu aññataram saṅkiliṭṭham āpattim āpannaḥ hoti yathārūpāya āpattiyāḥ na vuṭṭhānam paññāyati
translated: “Here, Kimbila, a monk has committed a certain defiled offense, one for which a means of rehabilitation is not prescribed.

analyzed: ayam vuccati antopūtibhāvoti
translated: This is called internal putridity.”

analyzed: pañcama
translated: The fifth.

analyzed: sayutta nikāya
translated: The Connected Discourses with Devadatta, the second section.

analyzed: āsīvisavagga
translated: The Collection on the Simile of the Snake

analyzed: avassuta pariyāya sutta
translated: The Mode of Conveying the Unbeautiful

original: Ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṁ nigrodhārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmin nigrodha ārāme
translated: At one time the Blessed One was dwelling among the Sakyans at Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Park.

original: Tena kho pana samayena kāpilavatthavānaṁ sakyānaṁ navaṁ santhāgāraṁ acirakāritaṁ hoti anajjhāvuṭṭhaṁ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā kenaci vā manussabhūtena.
analyzed: tena khalu pana samayena kāpilavatthavānam sakyānam navam santhāgāram acira kāritam hoti an ajjhāvuṭṭham samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā kenacid vā manussa bhūtena
translated: Now on that occasion a new assembly hall had just been built for the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu, and it had not yet been dwelled in by any contemplative, brahman, or anyone at all in human form.🔽Then the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu went to the Blessed One and,

original: Atha kho kāpilavatthavā sakyā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ🔽abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho kāpilavatthavā sakyā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: atha khalu kāpilavatthavāḥ sakyāḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamiṣu upasaṅkamitvā bhagavanta 🔽abhivādetvā ekamantam ekamantam nisīdisu ekamantam nisinnāḥ kho kāpilavatthavāḥ sakyāḥ bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: on arrival, having bowed down to him, sat to one side. As they were sitting there, they said to the Blessed One,🔽“Lord, a new assembly hall has just been built for the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu, and it has not yet been dwelled in by any contemplative, brahman, or anyone at all in human form.

original: “idha, bhante, kāpilavatthavānaṁ sakyānaṁ navaṁ santhāgāraṁ acirakāritaṁ anajjhāvuṭṭhaṁ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā kenaci vā manussabhūtena.
analyzed: idha bhante kāpilavatthavānam sakyānam navam santhāgāram acira kāritam an ajjhāvuṭṭham samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā kenacid vā manussa bhūtena
translated: “Venerable Sir, the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu have recently built a new meeting hall, which has not yet been slept in by any monastic or brahmin or any human being at all.

analyzed: ta bhante bhagavā paṭhamam paribhuñjatu
translated: May the Buddha be the first to use it.

original: Bhagavatā paṭhamaṁ paribhuttaṁ pacchā kāpilavatthavā sakyā paribhuñjissanti.
analyzed: bhagavatā paṭhamam paribhuttam pacchā kāpilavatthavā sakyā paribhuñjissanti
translated: After the Buddha has used it, the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu will use it.

original: Tadassa kāpilavatthavānaṁ sakyānaṁ dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
analyzed: tat assa kāpilavatthavānam sakyānam dīgharattam hitāya sukhāya ati
translated: That will be for the benefit and happiness of the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu for a long time.”

original: Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvena.🔽Atha kho kāpilavatthavā sakyā bhagavato adhivāsanaṁ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ
analyzed: adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvena  atha khalu kāpilavatthavāḥ sakyāḥ bhagavataḥ adhivāsanam viditvā uṭṭhāya āsanā bhagavanta
translated: The Buddha consented in silence.🔽Then the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu, understanding that he had consented, got up from their seats, bowed down, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right.

original: abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā yena navaṁ santhāgāraṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: abhivādetvā padakkhiṇam katvā yena navam santhāgāram tena upasaṅkamisu upasaṅkamitvā
translated: They then went to the new meeting hall,

original: sabbasanthariṁ santhāgāraṁ santharitvā āsanāni paññāpetvā udakamaṇikaṁ patiṭṭhāpetvā
analyzed: sabba santharim santhāgāram santharitvā āsanāni paññāpetvā udaka maṇikam patiṭṭhāpetvā
translated: where they spread it all over with felt rugs, prepared seats, set out a water vessel,🔽and

original: telappadīpaṁ āropetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: telappadīpam āropetvā yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamisu upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: and having lit a lamp of oil, they approached the Fortunate One, and after approaching, they said this to the Fortunate One:

original: “sabbasantharisanthataṁ, bhante, santhāgāraṁ, āsanāni paññattāni, udakamaṇiko patiṭṭhāpito, telappadīpo āropito.
analyzed: bhante santhāgāre āsanāni paññattāni udaka maṇikaḥ patiṭṭhāpito tela ppadīpaḥ āropito
translated: and they approached the Buddha and said to him, “The new assembly hall has been completely thatched, the seats have been prepared, the water vessel has been set out, and the oil lamp raised.

analyzed: yaḥ sadāni bhante bhagavā kālam maññati iti
translated: Now it’s up to you, Sir.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghena yena navaṁ santhāgāraṁ🔽tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā pāde pakkhāletvā santhāgāraṁ pavisitvā majjhimaṁ thambhaṁ
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya saddhim bhikkhu saṅghena yena navam santhāgāra  tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā pāde pakkhāletvā santhāgāram pavisitvā majjhimam thambha
translated: The Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe, and together with the Sangha of monks he approached the new assembly hall.

analyzed: nissāya purattha abhimukhaḥ nisīdi
translated: After washing his feet, he entered the building, and sat down against the central column, facing east.

original: Bhikkhusaṅghopi kho pāde pakkhāletvā santhāgāraṁ pavisitvā pacchimaṁ bhittiṁ nissāya puratthābhimukho nisīdi bhagavantaṁyeva purakkhatvā.
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅghaḥ api kho pāde pakkhāletvā santhāgāram pavisitvā pacchimam bhittim nissāya purattha abhimukhaḥ nisīdi bhagavantayā iva purakkhatvā
translated: The Sangha of monks washed their feet, entered the building, and sat down against the western wall, facing east, with the Buddha in front of them.

original: Kāpilavatthavā sakyā pāde pakkhāletvā santhāgāraṁ pavisitvā puratthimaṁ bhittiṁ nissāya pacchimābhimukhā nisīdiṁsu bhagavantaṁyeva purakkhatvā.
analyzed: kāpilavatthavā sakyā pāde pakkhāletvā santhāgāram pavisitvā puratthimam bhittim nissāya pacchima abhimukhāḥ nisīdisu bhagavantayā iva purakkhatvā
translated: The Sakyans of Kapilavatthu washed their feet, entered the assembly hall, and sat down facing the east, with the Buddha in front of them.

original: Atha kho bhagavā kāpilavatthave sakye bahudeva rattiṁ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṁsetvā uyyojesi:
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā kāpilavatthave sakye bahudeva rattim dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahasetvā uyyojesi
translated: Then the Buddha instructed, inspired, and gladdened them with a teaching. He then dismissed them,

analyzed: abhikkantā kho gotamā ratti
translated: “The night has passed, Gotamīs.

analyzed: yaḥ sadāni kālam maññatha ati
translated: Please go at your convenience.”

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho kāpilavatthavā sakyā bhagavato paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkamiṁsu.
analyzed: eva bhanta iti kho kāpilavatthavāḥ sakyāḥ bhagavato paṭissutvā uṭṭhāya āsanā bhagavantam abhivādetvā padakkhiṇam katvā pakkamisu
translated: “Yes, Sir.” The Sakyans of Kapilavatthu got up from their seats, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with their right side toward him, and left.

original: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkantesu kāpilavatthavesu sakyesu āyasmantaṁ mahāmoggallānaṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavā acira pakkantesu kāpilavatthavesu sakyesu āyasmantam mahāmoggallānam āmantesi
translated: Soon after they had left, the Buddha said to Venerable Mahāmoggallāna,

analyzed: vigata thinamiddhaḥ kho moggallāna bhikkhu saṅghaḥ
translated: “The Sangha of monks is free from dullness and drowsiness.

original: Paṭibhātu taṁ, moggallāna, bhikkhūnaṁ dhammī kathā.
analyzed: paṭibhātu ta moggallāna bhikkhūnam dhammī kathā
translated: Please give a teaching to the monks.

analyzed: piṭṭhi me āgilāyati
translated: My back hurts.

analyzed: tam aham āyamissāmi iti
translated: I’ll bring him to you.”

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavato paccassosi.
analyzed: eva bhante iti kho āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ bhagavataḥ paccassosi
translated: “Yes, Sir,” Ven. Mahā Moggallāna replied.

original: Atha kho bhagavā catugguṇaṁ saṅghāṭiṁ paññapetvā dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṁ kappesi, pāde pādaṁ accādhāya, sato sampajāno uṭṭhānasaññaṁ manasi karitvā.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā catugguṇam saṅghāṭim paññapetvā dakkhiṇena passena sīha seyyam kappesi pāde pādam accādhāya sataḥ sampajānaḥ uṭṭhāna saññam manasi karitvā
translated: Then the Blessed One, having arranged his outer robe folded in four, lay down on his right side in the lion’s sleeping posture, with one foot on top of the other, mindful & alert, having made a mental note to get up.

original: Tatra kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: tatra kho āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: There Ven. Mahā Moggallāna addressed the monks,

analyzed: āvuso bhikkhave ti
translated: “Venerable friends!”

original: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: āvuso ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmataḥ mahāmoggallānassa
translated: “Venerable friend!” those monks replied.

analyzed: āyasmai mahāmoggallānaḥ etat avoca
translated: Ven. Mahā Moggallāna said to them,

analyzed: avassuta pariyāyam ca vaḥ āvuso desessāmi an avassuta pariyāyam ca
translated: “Friends, I will teach you the way of explaining the unskillful and the way of explaining the skillful.

original: Taṁ suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tam suṇātha sādhukam manasi karotha bhāsissāmi iti
translated: Listen & pay close attention. I will speak.

original: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: evam āvuso ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmataḥ mahāmoggallānassa
translated: “As you say, friend,” the monks replied.

analyzed: āyasmai mahāmoggallānaḥ etat avoca
translated: Ven. Mahā Moggallāna said to them,

analyzed: kathā āvuso avassutaḥ hoti
translated: “And how, friends, is one unskillful?

original: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā piyarūpe rūpe adhimuccati, appiyarūpe rūpe byāpajjati, anupaṭṭhitakāyassatī viharati parittacetaso,
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam disvā piya rūpe rūpe adhimuccati appiya rūpe rūpe byāpajjati an upaṭṭhita kāya satī viharati paritta cetasaḥ
translated: There is the case where a monk, on seeing a form via the eye, is intent on pleasing forms, is intent on forms as a shelter, is intent on forms as a dwelling. He does not discern that form, does not discern the origination of form, does not discern the cessation of form, does not discern the allure of form, does not discern the drawbacks of form, does not discern the escape from form.

original: tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti …pe…
analyzed: tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti pe
translated: He does not discern that consciousness, does not discern the origination of consciousness, does not discern the cessation of consciousness, does not discern the allure of consciousness, does not discern the drawbacks of consciousness, does not discern the escape from consciousness.🔽On hearing a sound via the ear…

original: jivhāya rasaṁ sāyitvā …pe…🔽manasā dhammaṁ viññāya piyarūpe dhamme adhimuccati, appiyarūpe dhamme byāpajjati, anupaṭṭhitakāyassatī ca viharati parittacetaso,
analyzed: jivhāya rasam sāyitvā pe  manasā dhammam viññāya piya rūpe dhamme adhimuccati appiya rūpe dhamme byāpajjati an upaṭṭhita kāya satī ca viharati paritta cetasaḥ
translated: On smelling an odor via the nose…🔽On tasting a flavor via the tongue…🔽On touching a tactile sensation via the body…🔽On cognizing an idea via the intellect, he is intent on pleasing ideas, is intent on ideas as a shelter, is intent on ideas as a dwelling. He does not discern that idea, does not discern the origination of idea, does not discern the cessation of idea, does not discern the allure of idea, does not discern the drawbacks of idea, does not discern the escape from idea.

original: tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: He does not discern that consciousness, does not discern the origination of consciousness, does not discern the cessation of consciousness, does not discern the allure of consciousness, does not discern the drawbacks of consciousness, does not discern the escape from consciousness.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, āvuso, bhikkhu avassuto cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu …pe…🔽avassuto jivhāviññeyyesu rasesu …pe…
analyzed: ayam vuccati āvuso bhikkhu avassutaḥ cakkhu viññeyyesu rūpesu pe  avassutaḥ jivhā viññeyyesu rasesu pe
translated: This is called a monk who is not intent on the seen, who is not intent on the heard, who is not intent on the sensed, who is not intent on the cognized.

analyzed: avassutaḥ manaḥ viññeyyesu dhammesu
translated: He is not intent on the seen, who is not intent on the heard, who is not intent on the sensed, who is not intent on the cognized.

original: Evaṁvihāriñcāvuso, bhikkhuṁ cakkhuto cepi naṁ māro upasaṅkamati labhateva māro otāraṁ, labhati māro ārammaṇaṁ …pe…
analyzed: evavihārin ca āvuso bhikkhum cakkhutaḥ ce pi nam māraḥ upasaṅkamati labhateva māraḥ labhati māraḥ ārammaṇam pe
translated: If Mara comes upon a bhikkhu who abides in this way through the eye, Mara finds an opportunity to attack him, Mara finds an entry to the mind.

original: jivhāto cepi naṁ māro upasaṅkamati, labhateva māro otāraṁ, labhati māro ārammaṇaṁ …pe…
analyzed: jivhāto ce pi nam māro upasaṅkamati labhatā iva māro labhati māro ārammaṇam pe
translated: If Mara comes upon him through the ear…

original: manato cepi naṁ māro upasaṅkamati, labhateva māro otāraṁ, labhati māro ārammaṇaṁ.🔽Seyyathāpi, āvuso, naḷāgāraṁ vā tiṇāgāraṁ vā sukkhaṁ kolāpaṁ terovassikaṁ.🔽Puratthimāya cepi naṁ disāya puriso ādittāya tiṇukkāya upasaṅkameyya, labhetheva aggi otāraṁ, labhetha aggi ārammaṇaṁ;
analyzed: ce pi nam māro upasaṅkamati labhatā iva māro labhati māro  seyyathā api āvuso naḷāgāram vā tiṇa āgāram vā sukkham kolāpam terovassika  puratthimāya ce pi nam disāya purisaḥ ādittāya tiṇukkāya upasaṅkameyya labhetha iva aggi otāra labhetha aggi ārammaṇa
translated: through the mind, Mara finds an opportunity to attack him, Mara finds an entry to the mind.🔽Suppose there were a dry, sapless piece of wood, and a man came with an upper fire-stick, thinking: ‘I shall light a fire, I shall produce heat.’ What do you think, friends?

original: pacchimāya cepi naṁ disāya puriso ādittāya tiṇukkāya upasaṅkameyya …pe…
analyzed: pacchimāya ce pi nam disāya purisaḥ ādittāya tiṇukkāya upasaṅkameyya pe
translated: Would that man be able to light a fire and produce heat by rubbing the dry, sapless piece of wood with an upper fire-stick?

original: uttarāya cepi naṁ disāya …pe…🔽dakkhiṇāya cepi naṁ disāya …pe…
analyzed: uttarāya nam disāya  dakkhiṇāya nam disāya pe
translated: “If he came from the west…🔽from the north…🔽from the south…

analyzed: heṭṭhimataḥ ca ipi nam pe
translated: from below…

analyzed: uparimataḥ ca ipi nam
translated: from above…

original: yato kutoci cepi naṁ puriso ādittāya tiṇukkāya upasaṅkameyya, labhetheva aggi otāraṁ labhetha aggi ārammaṇaṁ.
analyzed: yatas kutocid ced ipi nam purisaḥ ādittāya tiṇukkāya upasaṅkameyya labhetha iva aggi otāram labhetha aggi ārammaṇa
translated: If a man were to come along with a burning grass torch and approach him from the front, he would find an entry and an access.

original: Evameva kho, āvuso, evaṁvihāriṁ bhikkhuṁ cakkhuto cepi naṁ māro upasaṅkamati, labhateva māro otāraṁ, labhati māro ārammaṇaṁ …pe…
analyzed: evam eva kho āvuso evavihārim bhikkhum cakkhutaḥ ce pi nam māraḥ upasaṅkamati labhateva māraḥ labhati māraḥ ārammaṇam pe
translated: In the same way, when a bhikkhu abides in this way, if Mara comes to him through the eye, he finds an entry and an access.

analyzed: nam māraḥ upasaṅkamati
translated: If Mara comes to him through the ear…

original: manato cepi naṁ māro upasaṅkamati, labhateva māro otāraṁ, labhati māro ārammaṇaṁ.
analyzed: ce pi nam māro upasaṅkamati labhatā iva māro labhati māro
translated: through the mind, he finds an entry and an access.

original: Evaṁvihāriñcāvuso, bhikkhuṁ rūpā adhibhaṁsu, na bhikkhu rūpe adhibhosi;🔽saddā bhikkhuṁ adhibhaṁsu, na bhikkhu sadde adhibhosi;🔽gandhā bhikkhuṁ adhibhaṁsu, na bhikkhu gandhe adhibhosi;🔽rasā bhikkhuṁ adhibhaṁsu, na bhikkhu rase adhibhosi;
analyzed: evavihārin ca āvuso bhikkhum rūpā adhibhasu na bhikkhu rūpe adhibhosi  saddā bhikkhum adhibhasu na bhikkhu sadde adhibhosi  gandhā bhikkhum adhibhasu na bhikkhu gandhe adhibhosi  rasā bhikkhum adhibhasu na bhikkhu rase adhibhosi
translated: “When a bhikkhu abides in this way, forms overpower him; he does not overpower forms.🔽Sounds overpower him; he does not overpower sounds.🔽Odours overpower him; he does not overpower odours.

original: phoṭṭhabbā bhikkhuṁ adhibhaṁsu, na bhikkhu phoṭṭhabbe adhibhosi;
analyzed: phoṭṭhabbā bhikkhum adhibhasu na bhikkhu phoṭṭhabbe adhibhosi
translated: Flavours overpower him; he does not overpower flavours.🔽Tangibles overpower him; he does not overpower tangibles.

original: dhammā bhikkhuṁ adhibhaṁsu, na bhikkhu dhamme adhibhosi.
analyzed: dhammā bhikkhum adhibhasu na bhikkhu dhamme adhibhosi
translated: the thoughts overwhelm him, he does not overwhelm the thoughts.

original: Ayaṁ vuccatāvuso, bhikkhu rūpādhibhūto, saddādhibhūto, gandhādhibhūto, rasādhibhūto,
analyzed: ayam vuccati āvuso bhikkhu rūpa adhibhūtaḥ sadda adhibhūtaḥ gandha adhibhūtaḥ rasa adhibhūtaḥ
translated: This bhikkhu is said to be overwhelmed by forms, overwhelmed by sounds, overwhelmed by odours, overwhelmed by tastes,

original: phoṭṭhabbādhibhūto, dhammādhibhūto, adhibhūto, anadhibhū, adhibhaṁsu naṁ pāpakā akusalā🔽dhammā saṅkilesikā ponobhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā.
analyzed: phoṭṭhabba adhibhūtaḥ dhamma adhibhūtaḥ adhibhūtaḥ naṃ pāpakāḥ akusalā  dhammā saṅkilesikā ponobhavikā sadarā dukkha vipākā āyatim jāti jarā maraṇiyā
translated: overwhelmed by tactile objects, overwhelmed by thoughts, overwhelmed, not overwhelming; the evil unwholesome states overwhelm him, and he does not overwhelm the evil unwholesome states.

analyzed: evam kho āvuso avassutaḥ hoti
translated: Thus he is called one who is overcome.

original: Kathañcāvuso, anavassuto hoti?🔽Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā piyarūpe rūpe nādhimuccati, appiyarūpe rūpe na byāpajjati, upaṭṭhitakāyassati ca viharati appamāṇacetaso,
analyzed: kathañca āvuso an avassutaḥ hoti  idha āvuso bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam disvā piya rūpe rūpe na adhimuccati appiya rūpe rūpe na byāpajjati upaṭṭhita kāyassati ca viharati appamāṇa cetasaḥ
translated: “And how, friends, is one not overcome?🔽Here, having seen a form with the eye, a bhikkhu is not intent on an agreeable form and is not repelled by a disagreeable form. He abides with a mind free from affliction, and free from wrong thought. He has established mindfulness directed to the body, and his mind is rightly concentrated in samādhi.

original: tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti …pe…
analyzed: tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti pe
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the eye.’

analyzed: jivhāya rasam sāyitvā pe
translated: Having sensed a taste with the tongue…

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya piyarūpe dhamme nādhimuccati, appiyarūpe dhamme na byāpajjati, upaṭṭhitakāyassati ca viharati appamāṇacetaso,
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya piya rūpe dhamme na adhimuccati appiya rūpe dhamme na byāpajjati upaṭṭhita kāyassati ca viharati appamāṇa cetasaḥ
translated: When he has had consciousness arisen with contact as condition, he does not cling to it, does not welcome it, and does not remain holding to it.

original: tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: He understands as it really is the liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, wherein those evil unwholesome states that have arisen cease without remainder.

original: Ayaṁ vuccatāvuso, bhikkhu anavassuto cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu …pe…🔽anavassuto manoviññeyyesu dhammesu.
analyzed: ayam vuccati āvuso bhikkhu anavassutaḥ cakkhu viññeyyesu rūpesu pe  an avassutaḥ manaḥ viññeyyesu dhammesu
translated: “A bhikkhu who is thus liberated in mind and liberated by wisdom,🔽is called a bhikkhu who is not assailed by Mara, who has crossed over attachment to the world, who has untied the knots of existence, who has made an end of suffering.”

original: Evaṁvihāriñcāvuso, bhikkhuṁ cakkhuto cepi naṁ māro upasaṅkamati, neva labhati māro otāraṁ, na labhati māro ārammaṇaṁ …pe…🔽jivhāto cepi naṁ māro upasaṅkamati …pe…
analyzed: evavihārin ca āvuso bhikkhum cakkhutaḥ ce pi nam māraḥ upasaṅkamati na iva labhati māraḥ na labhati māraḥ ārammaṇam pe  nam māraḥ upasaṅkamati
translated: “Friends, when a bhikkhu is thus dwelling, if Mara approaches him through the eye, Mara finds no entry, Mara finds no footing.

original: manato cepi naṁ māro upasaṅkamati, neva labhati māro otāraṁ, na labhati māro ārammaṇaṁ.
analyzed: ce pi nam māro upasaṅkamati na iva labhati māro na labhati māro
translated: If Mara approaches him through the ear… through the nose… through the tongue… through the body… through the mind, Mara finds no entry, Mara finds no footing.

original: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, kūṭāgāraṁ vā sālā vā bahalamattikā addāvalepanā.
analyzed: sā iyyathā api āvuso kūṭāgāram vā sālā vā bahala mattikā addāva lepanā
translated: It is just as a palace or a pavilion with a peaked roof, plastered inside and outside, shut off, secured by bars, with shuttered windows, in which the sun and moon have disappeared, and darkness has set in;

original: Puratthimāya cepi naṁ disāya puriso ādittāya tiṇukkāya upasaṅkameyya, neva labhetha aggi otāraṁ, na labhetha aggi ārammaṇaṁ …pe…🔽pacchimāya cepi naṁ …🔽uttarāya cepi naṁ …
analyzed: puratthimāya ce pi nam disāya puriso ādittāya tiṇukkāya upasaṅkameyya na iva labhetha aggi otāra na labhetha aggi ārammaṇam pe  pacchimāya ca ipi nam  uttarāya ca ipi nam
translated: If a man came from the west…🔽from the north…🔽from the south…

analyzed: dakkhiṇāya cepi nam  heṭṭhimataḥ ca ipi nam
translated: from below…

analyzed: uparimataḥ ca ipi nam
translated: from above…

original: yato kutoci cepi naṁ puriso ādittāya tiṇukkāya upasaṅkameyya, neva labhetha aggi otāraṁ, na labhetha aggi ārammaṇaṁ.🔽Evameva kho, āvuso, evaṁvihāriṁ bhikkhuṁ cakkhuto cepi naṁ māro upasaṅkamati, neva labhati māro otāraṁ, na labhati māro ārammaṇaṁ …pe…
analyzed: yatas kutocid ced ipi nam purisaḥ ādittāya tiṇukkāya upasaṅkameyya na iva labhetha aggi otāra na labhetha aggi ārammaṇa  evam eva kho āvuso evavihārim bhikkhum cakkhutaḥ ce pi nam māraḥ upasaṅkamati na iva labhati māraḥ na labhati māraḥ ārammaṇam pe
translated: from any direction with a blazing grass-torch, he would not be able to set fire to the ocean or make it boil.🔽So too, friend, when a bhikkhu abides thus, if Mara comes to him through the eye, Mara does not find an opportunity or a point of entry.

original: manato cepi naṁ māro upasaṅkamati, neva labhati māro otāraṁ, na labhati māro ārammaṇaṁ.
analyzed: ce pi nam māro upasaṅkamati na iva labhati māro na labhati māro
translated: If Mara comes to him through the ear… through the nose… through the tongue… through the body… through the mind, Mara does not find an opportunity or a point of entry.

original: Evaṁvihārī cāvuso, bhikkhu rūpe adhibhosi, na rūpā bhikkhuṁ adhibhaṁsu;
analyzed: eva vihārī ca āvuso bhikkhu rūpe adhibhosi na rūpā bhikkhum
translated: “A bhikkhu who abides thus has conquered forms, forms do not conquer him;

original: sadde bhikkhu adhibhosi, na saddā bhikkhuṁ adhibhaṁsu;🔽gandhe bhikkhu adhibhosi, na gandhā bhikkhuṁ adhibhaṁsu;
analyzed: sadde bhikkhu adhibhosi na saddā bhikkhum adhibhasu  gandhe bhikkhu adhibhosi na gandhā bhikkhum adhibhasu
translated: He has conquered sound …🔽He has conquered smell …

original: rase bhikkhu adhibhosi, na rasā bhikkhuṁ adhibhaṁsu;🔽phoṭṭhabbe bhikkhu adhibhosi, na phoṭṭhabbā bhikkhuṁ adhibhaṁsu;
analyzed: rase bhikkhu adhibhosi na rasā bhikkhum  phoṭṭhabbe bhikkhu adhibhosi na phoṭṭhabbāḥ bhikkhum adhibhasu
translated: He has conquered taste …🔽He has conquered the tactile …

original: dhamme bhikkhu adhibhosi, na dhammā bhikkhuṁ adhibhaṁsu.
analyzed: dhamme bhikkhu adhibhosi na dhammā bhikkhum adhibhasu
translated: He has conquered thoughts, and thoughts do not conquer him.

original: Ayaṁ vuccatāvuso, bhikkhu rūpādhibhū, saddādhibhū, gandhādhibhū, rasādhibhū, phoṭṭhabbādhibhū,
analyzed: ayam vuccati āvuso bhikkhu rūpa adhibhū sadda adhibhū gandha adhibhū rasa adhibhū phoṭṭhabba adhibhū
translated: This is called a monk who has conquered form, sound, smell, taste, tactile,

original: dhammādhibhū, adhibhū, anadhibhūto, adhibhosi te pāpake akusale dhamme saṅkilesike
analyzed: dhamma adhibhū adhibhū an adhibhūtaḥ adhibhosi te pāpake akusale dhamme saṅkilesike
translated: and thoughts. He has conquered, he is not conquered. He has conquered the bad, unwholesome qualities that defile,

analyzed: ponobhavike sadare dukkha vipāke āyatim jāti jarā maraṇiye
translated: that lead to renewed existence, that bring trouble, that result in suffering, and that lead to future birth, aging, and death.

analyzed: evam kho āvuso an avassutaḥ hoti iti
translated: In this way, a monk is not defiled.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā uṭṭhahitvā āyasmantaṁ mahāmoggallānaṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavā uṭṭhahitvā āyasmantam mahāmoggallānam āmantesi
translated: Then the Buddha got up and addressed Ven. Mahā Moggallāna:

analyzed: sādhu sādhu moggallāna
translated: “Good, good, Moggallāna!

original: Sādhu kho tvaṁ, moggallāna, bhikkhūnaṁ avassutapariyāyañca anavassutapariyāyañca abhāsī”ti.
analyzed: sādhu kho tva moggallāna bhikkhūnam avassuta pariyāyam ca an avassuta pariyāyam ca abhāsi iti
translated: It’s good that you have spoken this Dhamma exposition on the unintoxicated and the intoxicated.”

analyzed: idam avoce āyasmai mahāmoggallānaḥ
translated: The venerable Maha Moggallana said this.

analyzed: samanuññaḥ satthā ahosi
translated: The Teacher approved.

original: Attamanā te bhikkhū āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
analyzed: attamanāḥ te bhikkhū āyasmataḥ mahāmoggallānassa bhāsitam abhinandunti
translated: The monks were satisfied and delighted in the venerable Maha Moggallana’s words.

analyzed: chaṭṭha
translated: The sixth.🔽The Connected Discourses with Devadatta,

analyzed: sayutta nikāya  āsīvisavagga
translated: The Chapter with Ājīvaka Nigrodha,

analyzed: dukkhadhammasutta
translated: The Discourse on the Nature of Suffering

original: “Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbesaṁyeva dukkhadhammānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.🔽Tathā kho panassa kāmā diṭṭhā honti, yathāssa kāme passato, yo kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapariḷāho, so nānuseti.
analyzed: yatas kho bhikkhave bhikkhu sabbesayā iva dukkha dhammānam samudayam ca atthaṅgamam ca yathābhūtam pajānāti  tathā kho panassa kāmāḥ diṭṭhāḥ honti yathā assa kāme passataḥ yaḥ kāmesu kāma chandaḥ kāma snehaḥ kāma mucchā kāma pariḷāhaḥ saḥ na anuseti
translated: “Monks, when a monk truly understands the origin and the ending of all things that partake of the nature of suffering,🔽he sees things in such a way that, when he sees them, desire and lust do not invade his mind.

original: Tathā kho panassa cāro ca vihāro ca anubuddho hoti, yathā carantaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā nānusenti.
analyzed: tathā kho panassa cāraḥ ca vihāraḥ ca anubuddhaḥ hoti yathā carantam viharantam abhijjhā domanassāḥ pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na anusenti
translated: He has penetrated the course and the way on which bad, unwholesome qualities do not invade his mind.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, sabbesaṁyeva dukkhadhammānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave sabbesayā iva dukkha dhammānam samudayam ca atthaṅgamam ca yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: “And how does a monk understand as it really is the origin and passing away of all things that are painful?

original: ‘Iti rūpaṁ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
analyzed: iti rūpa iti rūpassa samudayaḥ iti rūpassa atthaṅgamaḥ
translated: ‘Such is form, such its origin, such its passing away;

analyzed: iti vedanā
translated: such is feeling …

analyzed: iti saññā
translated: such is perception …

analyzed: iti saṅkhārāḥ
translated: such are volitional formations …

original: iti viññāṇaṁ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti—
analyzed: iti viññāṇaḥ iti viññāṇassa samudayaḥ iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamaḥ ti
translated: such is consciousness, such its origin, such its passing away.’

original: evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbesaṁyeva dukkhadhammānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu sabbesayā iva dukkha dhammānam samudayam ca atthaṅgamam ca yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: It is in such a way that a monk understands as it really is the origin and passing away of all things that are painful.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno kāmā diṭṭhā honti? Yathāssa kāme passato, yo kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapariḷāho, so nānuseti.
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhunaḥ kāmāḥ diṭṭhāḥ honti yathā assa kāme passataḥ yaḥ kāmesu kāma chandaḥ kāma snehaḥ kāma mucchā kāma pariḷāhaḥ saḥ na anuseti
translated: “And how does a monk see the danger in sensual pleasures?

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, aṅgārakāsu sādhikaporisā puṇṇā aṅgārānaṁ vītaccikānaṁ vītadhūmānaṁ.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave aṅgārakāsu sādhika porisā puṇṇāḥ aṅgārānam
translated: Suppose there were a charcoal pit deeper than a man’s height, filled with glowing coals without flame or smoke.

original: Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhapaṭikūlo. Tamenaṁ dve
analyzed: atha purisaḥ āgaccheyya jīvitu kāmaḥ a maritu kāmaḥ sukha kāmaḥ dukkha paṭikūlo tam enam dve
translated: Then a man came who wanted to live and not to die, who wanted pleasure and recoiled from pain. Two strong men grabbed him by both arms and dragged him towards the charcoal pit, saying: ‘In, sir, into the charcoal pit!’

original: balavanto purisā nānābāhāsu gahetvā, taṁ aṅgārakāsuṁ upakaḍḍheyyuṁ. So iticīticeva kāyaṁ sannāmeyya.
analyzed: balavantaḥ purisāḥ nānā bāhāsu gahetvā tam aṅgāraka asum upakaḍḍheyyu saḥ iticiticā iva kāyam sannāmeyya
translated: and strong men would grab him by his arms and legs and drag him towards the pit of glowing embers.

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: And why is that?

original: Ñātañhi, bhikkhave, tassa purisassa imañcāhaṁ aṅgārakāsuṁ papatissāmi, tatonidānaṁ maraṇaṁ vā nigacchissāmi maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhanti.
analyzed: ñātam hi bhikkhave tassa purisassa imam ca aham aṅgāraka asum papatissāmi tatonidānam maraṇam vā nigacchissāmi maraṇa mattam vā dukkhanti
translated: Because that man knows: ‘If I fall into this pit of glowing embers, it will lead to my death or deadly suffering.’

original: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno aṅgārakāsūpamā kāmā diṭṭhā honti, yathāssa kāme passato, yo kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapariḷāho, so nānuseti.
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhunaḥ aṅgārakāsu upamā kāmāḥ diṭṭhāḥ honti yathā assa kāme passataḥ yaḥ kāmesu kāma chandaḥ kāma snehaḥ kāma mucchā kāma pariḷāhaḥ saḥ na anuseti
translated: In the same way, monks, a monk sees sensual pleasures as a pit of glowing embers, so that when he sees sensual pleasures, the desire, affection, enjoyment, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures do not arise in him.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno cāro ca vihāro ca anubuddho hoti, yathā carantaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā nānussavanti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhuno cāraḥ ca vihāraḥ ca anubuddhaḥ hoti yathā carantam viharantam abhijjhā domanassāḥ pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na anussavanti
translated: And how is a monk’s conduct and resort developed so that evil unwholesome states do not flow in on him?

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso bahukaṇṭakaṁ dāyaṁ paviseyya. Tassa puratopi kaṇṭako,
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave purisaḥ bahu kaṇṭakam dāyam paviseyya tassa puratas api kaṇṭakaḥ
translated: Suppose a man were to enter a thorny jungle,

original: pacchatopi kaṇṭako, uttaratopi kaṇṭako, dakkhiṇatopi kaṇṭako, heṭṭhatopi kaṇṭako,
analyzed: pacchatas api kaṇṭakaḥ uttaratas api kaṇṭakaḥ dakkhiṇatas api kaṇṭakaḥ heṭṭhatas api kaṇṭakaḥ
translated: There are thorns to the west, to the north, to the south, below, and above.

original: uparitopi kaṇṭako. So satova abhikkameyya, satova paṭikkameyya: ‘mā maṁ kaṇṭako’ti.
analyzed: uparitas pi kaṇṭako saḥ sataḥ iva abhikkameyya sataḥ iva paṭikkameyya mā mama kaṇṭako ti
translated: So he should go forward and return mindfully, thinking, ‘May no thorn hurt me.’

original: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yaṁ loke piyarūpaṁ sātarūpaṁ, ayaṁ vuccati ariyassa vinaye kaṇṭako”ti.
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave yam loke piya rūpam sāta rūpa ayam vuccati ariyassa vinaye kaṇṭakaḥ ti
translated: So too, bhikkhus, whatever in the world is agreeable and pleasurable is called a thorn in the Noble One’s Discipline.”

original: Iti viditvā saṁvaro ca asaṁvaro ca veditabbo.
analyzed: iti viditvā savaraḥ ca asavaraḥ ca veditabbo
translated: When this is known, restraint and non-restraint should be understood.

analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave a savaraḥ hoti
translated: “And how, bhikkhus, is there non-restraint?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā piyarūpe rūpe adhimuccati, appiyarūpe rūpe byāpajjati, anupaṭṭhitakāyassati ca viharati parittacetaso,
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam disvā piya rūpe rūpe adhimuccati appiya rūpe rūpe byāpajjati an upaṭṭhita kāyassati ca viharati paritta cetasaḥ
translated: Here, bhikkhus, having seen a form with the eye, a bhikkhu is intent on a pleasing form and repelled by a displeasing form. He abides with his body as though stirred, with his mind as though stirred, with his mindfulness as though stirred, and with his heart as though torn asunder.

original: tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti …pe…
analyzed: tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti pe
translated: He does not understand as it really is that liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, wherein those evil unwholesome states cease without remainder.

analyzed: jivhāya rasam sāyitvā pe
translated: Having sensed a mental phenomenon with the mind, he is intent on a pleasing mental phenomenon and repelled by a displeasing mental phenomenon.

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya piyarūpe dhamme adhimuccati, appiyarūpe dhamme byāpajjati, anupaṭṭhitakāyassati ca viharati parittacetaso,
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya piya rūpe dhamme adhimuccati appiya rūpe dhamme byāpajjati an upaṭṭhita kāyassati ca viharati paritta cetasaḥ
translated: When he has known with the mind a mind-object, he does not grasp at any theme in it that is pleasing or appealing. He abides with his mind not subject to bondage, and he understands as it actually is the escape from the arisen mind-object.

original: tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: He does not understand as it actually is the mind that has more powerful taints, the mind that is freed from powerful taints, the mind with powerful fetters, the mind with slight fetters, the mind with gross defilements, the mind with slight defilements, the concentrated mind, the unconcentrated mind, the liberated mind, and the unliberated mind.

analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave asavaraḥ hoti
translated: This is how there is non-restraint.

analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave savaraḥ hoti
translated: “And how, bhikkhus, is there restraint?🔽Here, bhikkhus, having seen a form with the eye, a bhikkhu does not grasp at its signs and features. Since, if he left the eye faculty unrestrained, bad, unwholesome states of longing and dejection might invade him, he practices restraint over it, he guards the eye faculty, he undertakes the restraint, of the eye faculty.

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā piyarūpe rūpe nādhimuccati, appiyarūpe rūpe na byāpajjati, upaṭṭhitakāyassati ca viharati appamāṇacetaso,
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam disvā piya rūpe rūpe na adhimuccati appiya rūpe rūpe na byāpajjati upaṭṭhita kāyassati ca viharati appamāṇa cetasaḥ
translated: He understands as it actually is the escape from the arisen eye-consciousness element and from forms. …🔽Having sensed a mind-object with the mind, he does not grasp at any theme in it that is pleasing or appealing. He abides with his mind not subject to bondage, and he understands as it actually is the escape from the arisen mind-object.

original: tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti …pe…🔽jivhāya rasaṁ sāyitvā …pe…
analyzed: tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti pe 🔽jivhāya rasam sāyitvā pe
translated: He understands as it actually is the mind that has more powerful taints, the mind that is freed from powerful taints, the mind with powerful fetters, the mind with slight fetters, the mind with gross defilements, the mind with slight defilements, the concentrated mind, the unconcentrated mind, the liberated mind, and the unliberated mind.

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya piyarūpe dhamme nādhimuccati, appiyarūpe dhamme na byāpajjati, upaṭṭhitakāyassati ca viharati appamāṇacetaso,
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya piya rūpe dhamme na adhimuccati appiya rūpe dhamme na byāpajjati upaṭṭhita kāyassati ca viharati appamāṇa cetasaḥ
translated: When he has had that thought, he does not grasp at its theme and does not relish it.

original: tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘This is the path, this is not the path.’

analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave savaraḥ hoti
translated: This is how restraint is undertaken.

original: Tassa ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno evaṁ carato evaṁ viharato kadāci karahaci satisammosā
analyzed: tassa ce bhikkhave bhikkhuno evam carataḥ evam viharataḥ kadāci karahaci sati sammosā
translated: “If, while he is living thus, from time to time,

original: uppajjanti, pāpakā akusalā sarasaṅkappā saṁyojaniyā, dandho, bhikkhave, satuppādo.
analyzed: uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā sara saṅkappā sayojaniyā dandhaḥ bhikkhave satuppādo
translated: evil unwholesome thoughts connected with desire, with hate, and with delusion, assail this bhikkhu,

original: Atha kho naṁ khippameva pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṁ gameti.
analyzed: atha kho nam khippam eva pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvam gameti
translated: then the thought occurs to him: ‘Evil unwholesome thoughts have arisen in me connected with desire, with hate, and with delusion.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso divasaṁsantatte ayokaṭāhe dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave purisaḥ divasa santatte ayaḥ kaṭāhe dve vā tīṇi vā udaka phusitāni
translated: Suppose a man were to throw a heavy stone into a deep pool of water.

original: nipāteyya. Dandho, bhikkhave, udakaphusitānaṁ nipāto, atha kho naṁ khippameva parikkhayaṁ
analyzed: nipāteyya dandhaḥ bhikkhave udaka phusitānam nipātaḥ atha kho nam khippam eva parikkhaya
translated: would be slow.🔽The falling of the water-drops is slow, bhikkhus, but their destruction is quick.

analyzed: pariyādānam gaccheyya
translated: would fall slowly, and would soon be exhausted and used up.

original: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, tassa ce bhikkhuno evaṁ carato, evaṁ viharato kadāci karahaci
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave tassa ce bhikkhuno evam carataḥ evam viharataḥ kadāci karahaci
translated: So too, bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu lives thus, it may be that now and then

original: satisammosā uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā sarasaṅkappā saṁyojaniyā, dandho, bhikkhave,
analyzed: sati sammosāḥ uppajjanti pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ sara saṅkappāḥ sayojaniyāḥ dandhaḥ bhikkhave
translated: evil unwholesome thoughts, connected with desire, associated with desire, giving rise to the pursuit of sensuality,

original: satuppādo. Atha kho naṁ khippameva pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṁ gameti.
analyzed: atha kho nam khippam eva pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvam gameti
translated: arise in him. But they quickly vanish, vanish fast, as though cut by a sword.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno cāro ca vihāro ca anubuddho hoti; yathā carantaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā nānussavanti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhuno cāraḥ ca vihāraḥ ca anubuddhaḥ hoti yathā carantam viharantam abhijjhā domanassāḥ pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na anussavanti
translated: Thus, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu’s conduct and way of life are fully developed, so that evil unwholesome thoughts, connected with desire, associated with desire, giving rise to the pursuit of sensuality, do not invade his mind.

original: Tañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṁ evaṁ carantaṁ evaṁ viharantaṁ rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā sālohitā vā, bhogehi abhihaṭṭhuṁ pavāreyyuṁ:
analyzed: tat ce bhikkhave bhikkhum evam carantam evam viharantam rājānaḥ vā rāja mahāmattāḥ vā mittāḥ vā amaccāḥ vā ñātī vā sālohitāḥ vā bhogehi abhihaṭṭhum pavāreyyu
translated: “If, bhikkhus, kings or royal ministers, friends, colleagues, kinsmen, or relatives were to invite a bhikkhu who lives thus,

original: ‘ehi, bho purisa, kiṁ te ime kāsāvā anudahanti,
analyzed: ehi bho purisa kim te ime kāsāvāḥ anudahanti
translated: ‘Come, good man, why do you torment yourself with these ochre robes?

analyzed: kim muṇḍo kapālam anucarasi
translated: Why do you go about with a shaven head and carry an alms bowl?

original: ehi hīnāyāvattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjassu, puññāni ca karohī’ti.
analyzed: ehi hīnāya avattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjassu puññāni ca karohi iti
translated: Come, turn back to the lower life and enjoy yourself and do meritorious deeds.’

original: So vata, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṁ caranto evaṁ viharanto sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissatīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā. Atha mahājanakāyo
analyzed: saḥ vata bhikkhave bhikkhu evam carantaḥ evam viharantaḥ sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattissati iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati  sā iyyathā api bhikkhave gaṅgā nadī pācīna ninnā pācīna poṇā pācīna pabbhārā atha mahā jana kāyaḥ
translated: It is impossible, monks, for a monk who conducts himself and behaves like this to abandon the training and return to the lower life.🔽Suppose, monks, a great many people came with pickaxes and baskets, thinking:

original: āgaccheyya kuddālapiṭakaṁ ādāya: ‘mayaṁ imaṁ gaṅgaṁ nadiṁ pacchāninnaṁ karissāma
analyzed: āgaccheyya kuddāla piṭakam ādāya mayam imam gaṅgam nadim pacchāninnam karissāma
translated: ‘We will make this Gaṅgā river flow backwards,

analyzed: pacchā apoṇam pacchā pabbhāranti
translated: make it flow westwards instead of eastwards.’

analyzed: tam kim maññatha bhikkhave
translated: What do you think, monks?

original: api nu kho so mahājanakāyo gaṅgaṁ nadiṁ pacchāninnaṁ kareyya pacchāpoṇaṁ pacchāpabbhāran”ti?
analyzed: api nu kho saḥ mahā jana kāyaḥ gaṅgam nadim pacchāninnam kareyya pacchā poṇam pacchā pabbhāranti
translated: Would that great many people be able to make the Gaṅgā river flow backwards?”

analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: “And why not?”

analyzed: gaṅgā bhante nadī pācīna ninnā pācīna poṇā pācīna pabbhārā
translated: “Because the Gaṅgā river flows eastwards, flows inclined and prone to the east, and flows having gone to the east.

original: sā na sukarā pacchāninnā kātuṁ pacchāpoṇā pacchāpabbhārā.
analyzed: sā na sukarā pacchā ninnā kātum pacchā poṇā pacchā pabbhārā
translated: It’s not easy to make it bend backward, to make it bow, or to make it break backward.

original: Yāvadeva ca pana so mahājanakāyo kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
analyzed: yāvat eva ca pana saḥ mahā jana kāyaḥ kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assa ati
translated: And that great crowd would only suffer and be exhausted.”

original: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, tañce bhikkhuṁ evaṁ carantaṁ evaṁ viharantaṁ rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā sālohitā vā bhogehi abhihaṭṭhuṁ pavāreyyuṁ:
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave tat ce bhikkhum evam carantam evam viharantam rājānaḥ vā rāja mahāmattāḥ vā mittāḥ vā amaccāḥ vā ñātī vā sālohitāḥ vā bhogehi abhihaṭṭhum pavāreyyu
translated: “So too, monks, if kings or royal ministers, friends or colleagues, relatives or family members were to invite a monk who lives in this way and in this manner, saying,

original: ‘ehi, bho purisa, kiṁ te ime kāsāvā anudahanti,
analyzed: ehi bho purisa kim te ime kāsāvāḥ anudahanti
translated: ‘Come, good man, what do these colorful monastic robes do for you?

analyzed: kim muṇḍo kapālam anucarasi
translated: What do you need with a shaven head and face and with wearing a patchwork cloth?

original: ehi hīnāyāvattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjassu, puññāni ca karohī’ti.
analyzed: ehi hīnāya avattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjassu puññāni ca karohi iti
translated: Come, turn back to the lower life and enjoy yourself, indulging in worldly pleasures and making merit,’

original: So vata, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṁ caranto evaṁ viharanto sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissatīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: saḥ vata bhikkhave bhikkhu evam carantaḥ evam viharantaḥ sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattissati iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati
translated: it’s impossible that he would give up the training and return to the lower life.

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Yañhi taṁ, bhikkhave, cittaṁ dīgharattaṁ vivekaninnaṁ vivekapoṇaṁ vivekapabbhāraṁ, tathā hīnāyāvattissatīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī”ti.🔽Sattamaṁ.
analyzed: yat hi ta bhikkhave cittam dīgharattam viveka ninnam viveka poṇam viveka pabbhāra tathā hīnāya avattissati iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti  sattama
translated: It is not possible that a mind that has long been inclined towards seclusion, turned towards seclusion, and has been developed for a long time, would return to those inferior pursuits.”🔽The seventh section on the simile of the saw is finished.

analyzed: sayutta nikāya
translated: The Connected Discourses with Devadatta, the second section, is finished.

analyzed: āsīvisavagga
translated: The Collection of Long Sayings

analyzed: kisuka upama sutta
translated: The Simile of the Tree

original: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yenaññataro bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho aññataraḥ bhikkhu yena aññataraḥ bhikkhu tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā tam bhikkhum etat avoca
translated: Then a certain monk went to another monk and asked him,

original: “kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, bhikkhuno dassanaṁ suvisuddhaṁ hotī”ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā nu kho āvuso bhikkhuno dassanam su visuddham hoti iti
translated: “When is a monk’s view well purified?”

original: “Yato kho, āvuso, bhikkhu channaṁ phassāyatanānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhuno dassanaṁ suvisuddhaṁ hotī”ti.
analyzed: yatas kho āvuso bhikkhu channam phassa āyatanānam samudayam ca atthaṅgamam ca yathābhūtam pajānāti ettāvatā kho āvuso bhikkhuno dassanam su visuddham hoti iti
translated: “When a monk truly understands the origin and ending of the six spheres of contact, then his view is well purified.”

original: Atha kho so bhikkhu asantuṭṭho tassa bhikkhussa pañhaveyyākaraṇena, yenaññataro bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho saḥ bhikkhu asantuṭṭhaḥ tassa bhikkhussa pañha veyyākaraṇena yena aññataraḥ bhikkhu tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā tam bhikkhum etat avoca
translated: But that monk was not satisfied with the other’s answer. He then went to another monk and asked him the same question.

original: “kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, bhikkhuno dassanaṁ suvisuddhaṁ hotī”ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā nu kho āvuso bhikkhuno dassanam su visuddham hoti iti
translated: “In what way, friend, is a monk’s view well purified?”

original: “Yato kho, āvuso, bhikkhu pañcannaṁ upādānakkhandhānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhuno dassanaṁ suvisuddhaṁ hotī”ti.
analyzed: yatas kho āvuso bhikkhu pañcannam upādānakkhandhānam samudayam ca atthaṅgamam ca yathābhūtam pajānāti ettāvatā kho āvuso bhikkhuno dassanam su visuddham hoti iti
translated: “When a monk understands as they really are the origin and passing away of the five aggregates affected by clinging, in that way a monk’s view is well purified.”

original: Atha kho so bhikkhu asantuṭṭho tassa bhikkhussa pañhaveyyākaraṇena, yenaññataro bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho saḥ bhikkhu asantuṭṭhaḥ tassa bhikkhussa pañha veyyākaraṇena yena aññataraḥ bhikkhu tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā tam bhikkhum etat avoca
translated: Dissatisfied with the answer, the monk went to another monk and asked him the same question.

original: “kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, bhikkhuno dassanaṁ suvisuddhaṁ hotī”ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā nu kho āvuso bhikkhuno dassanam su visuddham hoti iti
translated: “In what way, friend, is a monk’s view well purified?”

original: “Yato kho, āvuso, bhikkhu catunnaṁ mahābhūtānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhuno dassanaṁ suvisuddhaṁ hotī”ti.
analyzed: yatas kho āvuso bhikkhu catunnam mahābhūtānam samudayañca atthaṅgamañca yathābhūtam pajānāti ettāvatā kho āvuso bhikkhuno dassanam su visuddham hoti iti
translated: “When a monk understands as they really are the origin and passing away of the four great elements, in that way a monk’s view is well purified.”

original: Atha kho so bhikkhu asantuṭṭho tassa bhikkhussa pañhaveyyākaraṇena, yenaññataro bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:🔽“kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, bhikkhuno dassanaṁ suvisuddhaṁ hotī”ti?
analyzed: atha kho saḥ bhikkhu asantuṭṭhaḥ tassa bhikkhussa pañha veyyākaraṇena yena aññataraḥ bhikkhu tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā tam bhikkhum etat avoca  kittāvatā nu kho āvuso bhikkhuno dassanam su visuddham hoti iti
translated: Dissatisfied with the answer of that monk, he went to another monk and asked him the same question.

original: “Yato kho, āvuso, bhikkhu yaṁ kiñci samudayadhammaṁ, sabbaṁ taṁ nirodhadhammanti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhuno dassanaṁ suvisuddhaṁ hotī”ti.
analyzed: yatas kho āvuso bhikkhu yam kiñci samudaya dhamma sabbam tam nirodha dhamman ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ettāvatā kho āvuso bhikkhuno dassanam su visuddham hoti iti
translated: “When a monk understands as it really is: ‘All that is subject to arising is subject to cessation,’ his view is well purified.”

original: Atha kho so bhikkhu asantuṭṭho tassa bhikkhussa pañhaveyyākaraṇena, yena bhagavā🔽tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca: “idhāhaṁ, bhante, yenaññataro
analyzed: atha kho so bhikkhu asantuṭṭhaḥ tassa bhikkhussa pañha veyyākaraṇena yena bhagavā  tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam etat avoca idha āha bhante yena aññataraḥ
translated: Dissatisfied with the answer of that monk, he went to the Blessed One,🔽bowed down, and sat to one side.

original: bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavocaṁ:🔽‘kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, bhikkhuno dassanaṁ suvisuddhaṁ hotī’ti?
analyzed: bhikkhu tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā tam bhikkhum etat avoca 🔽kittāvatā nu kho āvuso bhikkhuno dassanam su visuddham hoti iti
translated: “Here, Bhante, I went to a certain monk and asked him the same question,🔽and he answered me as you have done.

original: Evaṁ vutte, bhante, so bhikkhu maṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte bhante saḥ bhikkhu mam etat avoca
translated: When I had spoken, that bhikkhu said to me:
